{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"This recipe was developed from a banana muffin that had a similar crumbly top. When I saw Stephan eat the top and pick out the banana chunks, I realized a new dessert would be healthier, moister, and better appreciated. I was right, but be sure to serve this very warm and don't use very old, overripe bananas \u2014 the taste becomes a little intense for children. Mash and freeze such overripe bananas in a plastic container for a banana bread or other similar confections.", 'rating': u'2/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'50%', 'ingredient list': [u'4 large bananas', u'1/4 cup all-purpose flour', u'1/4 cup light brown sugar, firmly packed', u'1 cup rolled oats', u'1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon', u'1/8 teaspoon coarse salt', u'1/4 cup (1/2 stick) cold unsalted butter', u'Equipment: 9- by 13-inch baking pan'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat the oven to 400\xb0F. Have children grease a 9- by 13-inch baking dish.', u'Let the kids help you slice the bananas in half lengthwise with a table knife. Place the bananas cut side down in the prepared baking dish.', u'Have the children place the dry ingredients in a medium mixing bowl. Using a table knife, have the kids help you cut up the cold butter into little pieces and add them to the bowl. With clean hands, have the children work the butter into the dry ingredients until the mixture is crumbly. Then spread the crumble mixture over the bananas in an even layer, pressing down slightly.', u'Place the dish in the oven and bake until the crumble gets firm but not mushy and has turned golden in color, 10 to 15 minutes. Serve very warm.'], 'chef': u'n Fredericks', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/banana-crumble-102140', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 4 servings', 'recipe title': u'Banana Crumble', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'First the turkey is soaked overnight in a brine to improve flavor and ensure moist meat. (Be sure to use a pot large enough to hold both the brine and the turkey.) The smokiness of the turkey is offset beautifully by the tangy, sweet glaze, which incorporates two quintessential Napa Valley ingredients: wine and mustard.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'98%', 'ingredient list': [u'6 quarts water', u'2 large onions, quartered', u'1 cup coarse salt', u'1 cup chopped fresh ginger', u'3/4 cup (packed) golden brown sugar', u'4 large bay leaves', u'4 whole star anise', u'12 whole black peppercorns, crushed', u'1 13- to 14-pound turkey, giblets discarded', u'4 cups hickory smoke chips, soaked in water 30 minutes, drained', u'Disposable 9x6 1/4x1-inch aluminum broiler pans', u'2 large oranges, cut into wedges', u'1/4 cup olive oil', u'2 tablespoons oriental sesame oil', u'3/4 cup pure maple syrup', u'1/2 cup dry white wine', u'1/3 cup Dijon mustard', u'2 tablespoons (1/4 stick) butter', u'Serve accompanied by Winter Fruit Chutney'], 'preperation steps': [u'Combine first 8 ingredients in very large pot. Bring mixture to simmer, stirring until salt and sugar dissolve. Cool brine completely.', u'Rinse turkey inside and out. Place turkey in brine, pressing to submerge. Chill overnight, turning turkey twice.', u'If using charcoal barbecue: Mound charcoal briquettes in barbecue and burn until light gray. Using tongs, carefully divide hot briquettes into 2 piles, 1 pile at each side of barbecue. Sprinkle each pile with generous 1/2 cup hickory chips. Place empty broiler pan between piles. Position grill at least 6 inches above briquettes. Position vents on barbecue so that chips smoke and briquettes burn but do not flame.', u'If using gas or electric barbecue: Preheat barbecue with all burners on high. Turn off center burner and lower outside burners to medium-low heat. Place generous 1/2 cup hickory chips in each of 2 broiler pans. Set pans over 2 lit burners. Place empty broiler pan over unlit burner. Position grill at least 6 inches above burners.', u'Remove turkey from brine; discard brine. Pat turkey dry with paper towels. Place orange wedges in main cavity. Mix olive oil and sesame oil in small bowl. Brush over turkey. Arrange breast side up on grill, centering above empty broiler pan. Cover; cook until thermometer inserted into thickest part of thigh registers 160\xb0F, adding 1 cup hickory chips (and 6 briquettes if using charcoal barbecue) to barbecue every 30 minutes, about 3 hours.', u'Bring all ingredients to simmer in heavy medium saucepan.', u'Brush glaze over turkey; cover and cook until thermometer inserted into thickest part of thigh registers 180\xb0F, covering any dark areas of turkey with foil, about 1 hour longer. Transfer turkey to platter. Tent with foil and let stand 30 minutes.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/barbecued-turkey-with-maple-mustard-glaze-4366', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 8', 'recipe title': u'Barbecued Turkey with Maple-Mustard Glaze', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Cake balls are bite-sized balls made of crumbled cake mixed with frosting and covered in candy coating. They are super-easy to make and form the basis of endless variations of decorated cake pops, cupcake pops, and cake bites.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'78%', 'ingredient list': [u'18.25-ounce box cake mix', u'9-by-13-inch cake pan', u'Large mixing bowl', u'One 16-ounce container ready-made frosting', u'Large metal spoon', u'Wax paper', u'2 baking sheets', u'Plastic wrap', u'32 ounces (2 pounds) candy coating', u'Deep, microwave-safe plastic bowl', u'Toothpicks', u'Resealable plastic bag or squeeze bottle (optional)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Bake the cake as directed on the box, using a 9-by-13-inch cake pan. Let cool completely.', u'Once the cake is cooled, get organized and set aside plenty of time (at least an hour) to crumble, roll, and dip 4 dozen cake balls.', u'Crumble the cooled cake into a large mixing bowl. The texture of the cake causes it to crumble easily. Just cut a baked 9-by-13-inch cake into 4 equal sections. Remove a section from the pan, break it in half, and rub the two pieces together over a large bowl, making sure to crumble any large pieces that fall off. You can also use a fork to break any larger pieces of cake apart. Repeat with each section until the entire cake is crumbled into a fine texture. If you have large pieces mixed in, the cake balls may turn out lumpy and bumpy. You should not see any large pieces of cake.', u'Add three-quarters of the container of frosting. (You will not need the remaining frosting.) Mix it into the crumbled cake, using the back of a large metal spoon, until thoroughly combined. If you use the entire container, the cake balls will be too moist.', u'The mixture should be moist enough to roll into 1 1/2-inch balls and still hold a round shape. After rolling the cake balls by hand, place them on a wax paper-covered baking sheet.', u'Cover with plastic wrap and chill for several hours in the refrigerator, or place in the freezer for about 15 minutes. You want the balls to be firm but not frozen.', u"If you're making a project that calls for uncoated cake balls, stop here and proceed to decorate the cake balls, following the project instructions.", u'Place the candy coating in a deep, microwave-safe plastic bowl. These bowls make it easier to cover the cake balls completely with candy coating while holding the bowl without burning your fingers. (I usually work with about 16 ounces of coating at a time.)', u'Melt the candy coating, following the instructions on the package. Microwave on medium power for 30 seconds at a time, stirring with a spoon in between. You can also use a double boiler. Either way, make sure you do not overheat the coating.', u"Now you're ready to coat. Take a few cake balls at a time out of the refrigerator or freezer to work with. If they're in the freezer, transfer the rest of the balls to the refrigerator at this point, so they stay firm but do not freeze.", u'Place one ball at a time into the bowl of candy coating. Spoon extra coating over any uncoated areas of the cake ball to make sure it is completely covered in candy coating. Then lift out the cake ball with your spoon. Avoid stirring it in the coating, because cake crumbs can fall off into the coating.', u'Holding the spoon over the bowl, tap the handle of the spoon several times on the edge of the bowl until the excess coating falls off and back into the bowl. This technique also creates a smooth surface on the outside of the cake ball.', u'Transfer the coated cake ball to another wax paper-covered baking sheet to dry. Let the coated cake ball slide right off the spoon. Some coating may pool around the base of the ball onto the wax paper. If so, simply take a toothpick and use it to draw a line around the base of the cake ball before the coating sets. Once the coating sets, you can break off any unwanted coating.', u'Repeat with the remaining cake balls and let dry completely.', u'If you have extra candy coating left over, pour it into a resealable plastic bag (and then snip off the corner) or into a squeeze bottle and drizzle it over the tops in a zigzag motion to decorate.', u'You can make the cake balls ahead of time and store them in an airtight container on the counter or in the refrigerator for several days.', u"The cake balls will be easier to roll if you wash and dry your hands periodically during the rolling process. Dry your hands completely each time, and make sure you don't get water in the candy coating, as it can make it unusable.", u'You can use a mini ice cream scoop to get uniform-size cake balls.', u"If you don't need or want to make 48 cake balls, simply divide the cake in half for 24 cake balls or in quarters for 12 and freeze the remaining cake for later use. Remember to reduce the amount of frosting proportionally."], 'chef': u'Bakerella', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/basic-cake-balls-361550', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 48 cake balls', 'recipe title': u'Basic Cake Balls', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Editor's note: To make your own sourdough starter, follow Beranbaum's instructions.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'59%', 'ingredient list': [u'a heavy-duty mixer with dough hook attachment;', u'an 8-inch banneton or small colander lined with a towel;', u'a half sheet pan lined with a nonstick liner such as Silpain or parchment;', u'a baking stone OR baking sheet', u'sourdough starter: 1/3 cup (2 3/4 ounces or 75 grams)', u'\u2022 for storing: scant 1/4 cup (1.75 ounces or 50 grams)', u'\u2022 for this bread: 1 tablespoon plus 2 teaspoons (1 scant ounce or 25 grams)', u'bread flour: 1 1/3 cups, divided (7 ounces or 200 grams)', u'water, at room temperature (70 to 90\xb0F): 1/2 cup minus 1 tablespoon, divided (3.5 ounces or 100 grams)', u'bread flour: 1 1/4 cups (7 ounce or 200 grams)', u'water, at room temperature (70 to 90\xb0F): 2/3 liquid cup (5.5 ounces or 154 grams)', u'stiff sourdough starter (from above): 2/3 cup (5.25 ounces or 150 grams)', u'salt: 1 scant teaspsoon (scant 0.25 ounce or 6 grams)'], 'preperation steps': [u'The day before baking, first thing in the morning, feed (expand) the sourdough starter. (It will be ready to use or to rest refrigerated overnight after about 14 hours.) Allow the starter to sit at room temperature (70\xb0 to 80&Deg;F) for 1 hour before feeding it.', u'First, feed (refresh) and store some of the sourdough seed starter for future batches of bread (you will be increasing it by 2 1/2 times, from 50 grams to 125 grams):', u'Begin by tearing off a scant 1/4 cup (1.75 ounces/50 grams) of the starter. It will be soft and stretchy. Place it in a small bowl.', u"Add 1/3 cup (1.75 ounces/50 grams) of the flour and 1 tablespoon plus 2 teaspoons (1 scant ounce/25 grams) of the water. With a wooden spoon and then your hand, mix and knead together until all the flour is absorbed. The starter should be the consistency of a stiff biscuit dough. If after about 2 minutes of kneading there are still loose particles of flour, add water by the droplet. (Don't worry, too much water won't hurt it\u2014but during fermentation and resting, the dough becomes softer, and it is easier to work with the starter when it is firm and not sticky, so you don't lose any on your fingers or the bowl.)", u"Place this starter in a lightly oiled 1-cup storage container with a lid. Lightly oil the surface of the starter. Allow the starter to start to ferment at warm room temperature (75\xb0to 80\xb0F) before storing it in the refrigerator. If you are planning to bake more bread soon, you want the starter to ferment longer at room temperature so it will be more active sooner. If you are not planning to bake more bread for several days, you want to slow down the fermentation by refrigerating it sooner so that the yeast doesn't consume all the added flour.", u'If baking bread the next day or the day after feeding the starter, refrigerate the starter after 2 hours at room temperature.', u'If baking bread 3 days after feeding the starter, refrigerate the starter after 1 hour at room temperature.', u'If baking bread 1 week after feeding the starter, refrigerate the starter after 30 minutes at room temperature.', u'1. Give the starter the first feeding and allow it to ferment and rise (you will be increasing the starter by 4 times, from 25 grams to 100 grams). Tear off a scant 2 tablespoons (1 scant ounce/25 grams) of the sourdough starter (discard any remaining starter) and place it in a small bowl.', u'Add 1/3 cup (1.75 ounces/50 grams) of the flour and 1 tablespoon plus 2 teaspoons (1 scant ounce/25 grams) of the water. With a wooden spoon and then your hand, mix and knead together until all the flour is absorbed. If after about 2 minutes of kneading there are still loose particles of flour, add water by the droplet. The starter should be a rough dough that is very stiff but holds together, with no loose flour particles. It will measure a rounded 1/3 cup and weigh 3.5 ounces/100 grams.', u'Transfer the starter to an oiled 1-cup glass measure. Oil the top and press it down into the cup. It should measure about 1/3 cup in the glass measure. Cover the measuring cup tightly with greased plastic wrap and let rise (ideally at 75\xb0to 80\xb0F) until it has doubled, to 2/3 cup, 6 to 8 hours.', u'2. Give the starter the second feeding and allow the yeast to ferment and rise (you will be increasing it by 4 times, from 50 grams to 200 grams). Tear off a scant 1/4 cup (1.75 ounces/50 grams) of the starter and discard the remainder. Tear the starter into a few pieces and place in a medium bowl. Add the remaining 2/3 cup (3.5 ounces/100 grams) flour and 3 1/2 tablespoons (1.75 ounces/50 grams) water. With a wooden spoon and then your hand, mix and knead together until all the flour is absorbed. If after about 2 minutes of kneading there are still loose particles of flour, add water by the droplet. The starter should be a rough dough that is very stiff but holds together, with no loose flour particles. You will have a full 3/4 cup (7 ounces/200 grams).', u'Transfer the starter to an oiled 2-cup glass measure. Oil the top and press it down into the cup. It should measure about 3/4 cup in the glass measure. Cover the measuring cup tightly with greased plastic wrap and let rise (ideally at 75\xb0to 80\xb0F) until it has doubled, to 1 1/2 cups, about 6 hours. Refrigerate the starter if you are not ready to mix the dough\u2014up to 20 hours.', u'3. Mix the dough.', u'Mixer Method If you have refrigerated the starter, remove it to room temperature 1 hour before mixing the dough.', u'In the mixer bowl, place the flour. With the dough hook, on low speed (#2 if using a KitchenAid), gradually add the water until the flour is moistened enough to form a rough dough. Continue kneading on low speed for 3 minutes, enough to develop the gluten structure a little. Scrape down any bits of dough. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and allow the dough to rest for 20 minutes.', u'With oiled fingers, tear off 2/3 cup (5.25 ounces/150 grams) of the starter; discard the rest. Tear it into 4 pieces, roughly the same size. On low speed, knead it into the dough, about 2 minutes. Add the salt and continue kneading for 1 minute. Raise the speed to medium (#4 KitchenAid) and knead for 3 minutes. The dough will be barely tacky (sticky), smooth, and very elastic. If it is still very sticky, knead in a little flour. If it is not at all sticky, spray it with a little water and knead it. (The dough will measure about 2 cups and weigh about 17.7 ounces/502 grams.)', u'Hand Method If it has been refrigerated, remove the starter to room temperature 1 hour before mixing the dough.', u'With oiled fingers, tear off 2/3 cup (5.25 ounces/150 grams) of the starter; discard the rest. Tear it into 4 pieces, roughly the same size, and place it in a mixing bowl.', u'With a wooden spoon, stir in the water, stirring for a few seconds to soften the starter, then add all but 2 tablespoons of the flour and the salt. Continuing with the wooden spoon or using your hand, mix until the flour is moistened. Knead the dough in the bowl until it comes together, then scrape it onto a lightly floured counter. Knead the dough for 5 minutes, enough to develop the gluten structure a little, adding as little of the reserved 2 tablespoons flour as possible to keep it from sticking. (To prevent sticking, it helps to use your fingertips, not the palms of your hands.) Use a bench scraper to scrape up the dough and gather it together as you knead it. At this point, it will be very sticky. Cover it with the inverted bowl and allow it to rest for 20 minutes. (This rest will make the dough less sticky and easier to work with.)', u'Knead the dough for another 5 to 10 minutes or until it is very smooth and elastic. It should be barely tacky (sticky) to the touch. If the dough is still very sticky, add some or all of the remaining reserved flour or a little extra. (The dough will measure about 2 cups and weigh about 17.7 ounces/502 grams.)', u'Both Methods 4. Let the dough rise. Using an oiled spatula or dough scraper, scrape the dough into a 4-cup glass measuring cup or 1-quart food storage container, lightly greased with cooking spray or oil. Press down the dough so you can get an accurate measure, and lightly spray or oil the top. It will come to 2 cups. Cover the measuring cup with plastic wrap; or cover the container with a lid and, with a piece of tape, mark the side of the container at approximately where double the height of the dough would be. Allow the dough to rise (ideally at 75\xb0to 80\xb0F) for 1 hour. It will only have risen a little.', u'Scrape the dough onto a lightly floured counter. Gently push it down to deflate it, and stretch it into a rectangle (the exact size is not important). Give it 2 business letter turns. It will be soft and stretchy but a little firmer after each turn. Return the dough to the greased container and lightly spray or oil the top. Cover the container with a lid or plastic wrap and allow it to rise for another hour.', u'Stretch the dough again, give it 2 business letter turns, and return it to the container. Grease the top, cover, and allow it to rise until doubled, to 4 cups (1 quart), 4 to 5 hours.', u'5. Shape the dough and let it rise. Without deflating it, turn the dough out onto a floured counter and round it into a ball (see page 65). Set it in a floured banneton or a colander lined with a floured towel, seam side up. Pinch together the seam if it starts to pull apart. In the banneton, the dough will be about 2 inches from the top.', u'Spray the dough with oil or sprinkle lightly with flour and cover it with a large container or plastic wrap. Let the dough rise ideally at (75deg;to 80\xb0F.) until almost doubled, 3 to 4 hours. When it is pressed gently with a fingertip, the depression will very slowly fill in. In the banneton, the center of the dough will be 3/4 to 1 inch from the top.', u'6. Preheat the oven. Preheat the oven to 475\xb0F 1 hour before baking. Have an oven shelf at the lowest level and place an oven stone or baking sheet on it, and a cast-iron skillet or sheet pan on the floor of the oven, before preheating.', u"7. Slash and bake the dough. Very gently invert the dough onto the prepared baking sheet. (If you are using a colander and the risen bread is more than 1 inch below the top, you will need to support the bread when inverting it so that it doesn't fall and deflate. Cut a cardboard circle small enough to fit into the colander and touch the surface of the bread. Place a piece of parchment on top of the bread, place the cardboard on top, and invert it onto the cardboard. Then slide the bread, still on the parchment, onto the baking sheet.) For a more evenly rounded bread, it's fine to leave the dough unslashed. If you like the rustic appearance of a slashed top crust, with sharp scissors, sharp knife, or a single-edged razor blade, slash a 1/4-inch-deep cross in the dough. Because the skin of the dough is very dry, it will be difficult to slash; use a gentle hand so as not to deflate the dough.", u'Quickly but gently set the baking sheet on the hot baking stone or hot baking sheet. Toss 1/2 cup of ice cubes into the pan beneath and immediately shut the door. Bake for 5 minutes. Lower the oven to 450\xb0F and continue baking for 10 minutes. With a heavy pancake turner, lift the bread from the pan and set it directly on the stone, turning it around as you do so for even baking. Continue baking for 10 to 15 minutes or until the crust is deeply burnished and a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean (an instant-read thermometer inserted into the center will read about 212\xb0F). For a very crisp crust, prop the open door slightly ajar for the last 5 minutes of baking.', u'8. Cool the bread. Remove the bread from the oven, and transfer it to a wire rack to cool completely.', u'Quicker Sourdough Bread (with added commercial yeast)\u2002\u2002If your schedule requires speeding up the process (by about 25 percent), or if you feel more secure with the added reliability of commercial yeast, you can add up to 0.06 percent of the total weight of the flour in this recipe (including the flour contained in the starter). The total weight is 300 grams; 0.06 percent of 300 grams is about 0.2 gram or about 1/16 teaspoon instant yeast. This should be added after the autolyse (the 20-minute rest before the final mixing). At this low a percentage, it will not affect the acidity or flavor of the sourdough, but if it were added at the beginning, the commercial yeast would likely be killed by the acidity of the sourdough starter.', u'Basic Sourdough Bread with Extra Flavor and Keeping Quality\u2002\u2002If desired, you can replace 2 tablespoons (0.7 ounce/20 grams) of the bread flour with an equal measure or weight of whole wheat, kamut, or rye flour. (This is 6.5 percent of the total amount of flour in the recipe.)', u'French Country Boule\u2002\u2002Reduce the bread flour in the dough to 3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (4.5 ounces/130 grams) and add 1/3 cup (1.5 ounces/40 grams) medium rye flour and 3 tablespoons (1 ounce/30 grams) whole wheat flour. Also add 1 tablespoon of water.', u'In a very cold room, when yeast will take a long time to ferment, or a very warm one, when yeast will take a shorter time to ferment, you may want to adjust the amount of sourdough starter used in the dough.', u'To reduce the amount of stiff sourdough starter from 30 percent to 20 percent: Reduce the starter to a rounded 1/3 cup (3.5 ounces/100 grams). To the rest of the dough, add 1 full tablespoon (about 1 ounce/16.6 grams) water and 3 1/2 tablespoons (1 full ounce/33.3 grams) flour.', u'To increase the amount of stiff sourdough starter from 30 percent to 40 percent: Increase the starter to a full 3/4 cup (7 ounces/200 grams). From the rest of the dough, subtract 1 full tablespoon (about 1 ounce/16.6 grams) water and 3 1/2 tablespoons (1 full ounce/33.3 grams) flour.', u'\u2022 If you need more starter-to make 2 loaves at once, for \xadexample\u2014in Step 2, rather than discarding half, use the full 100 grams and increase it to 400 grams.', u'Flour: 100% Water: 68% Dough Starter: 30% Salt: 2%'], 'chef': u'Rose Levy Beranbaum', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/basic-sourdough-bread-351236', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u' Makes: a 6-by-3 1/2-inch-high round loaf/about 15 ounces/430 grams', 'recipe title': u'Basic Sourdough Bread', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Check your local farmers market or Chef's Garden (800-289-4644) for the geranium leaves or experiment with other leaves such as fresh basil or mint.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'87%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 cup heavy cream', u'2 tablespoons finely chopped pesticide-free rose-scented geranium (pelargonium) leaves', u'1/4 cup sugar', u'4 oz cream cheese, softened', u'3 cups blackberries (13 oz)', u'1 1/2 cups blueberries (8 oz)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Heat cream, geranium leaves, and sugar in a metal bowl set over a pot of simmering water, stirring until sugar is dissolved and cream is hot but not boiling, about 5 minutes. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'The clever topping is made with a cake mix.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'85%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 1-pound 2.25-ounce box yellow cake mix', u'14 tablespoons (13/4 sticks) chilled unsalted butter, cut into pieces', u'3/4 cup (packed) dark brown sugar', u'1/2 cup old-fashioned oats', u'1 teaspoon ground cinnamon', u'1 1/2 cups chopped pecans', u'2 1-pound bags frozen unsweetened blueberries', u'1 20-ounce can crushed pineapple in heavy syrup', u'Vanilla ice cream'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'At Las Ventanas this soup and a corn soup are ladled side by side into the serving bowl.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'92%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 tablespoons olive oil', u'1 1/2 cups chopped onion', u'8 garlic cloves, chopped', u'1/4 cup chopped jalape\xf1os with seeds', u'2 cups dried black beans (about 13 ounces)', u'1 tablespoon ground cumin', u'2 teaspoons ground coriander', u'8 cups (or more) vegetable stock or canned vegetable broth', u'1 cup coarsely chopped fresh cilantro', u'Lime wedges'], 'preperation steps': [u'Heat oil in heavy large pot over medium-high heat. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Makes enough for a 13-inch tart shell.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'80%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour', u'1 teaspoon salt', u'3/4 teaspoon black pepper', u'3/4 teaspoon sugar', u'11/4 sticks (10 tablespoons) cold unsalted butter, cut into bits', u'1/3 cup cold vegetable shortening', u'3 tablespoons sour cream', u'3 tablespoons ice water'], 'preperation steps': [u'Blend together flour, salt, pepper, sugar, butter, and shortening with your fingertips or a pastry blender until most of mixture resembles coarse meal with remainder in small (roughly pea-size) lumps.', u'Stir together sour cream and ice water, then stir into dough with a fork until incorporated. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Commonly served for breakfast in parts of Southeast Asia, this dish also makes a great dessert. Chinese black rice, sometimes called forbidden rice, works well, but if you live near a Southeast Asian market you can use this same method with the more traditional Thai black sticky rice.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'84%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 cup black rice', u'1/2 cup sugar', u'1 (13 1/2- to 15-oz) can unsweetened coconut milk, stirred well'], 'preperation steps': [u'Bring rice, 3 cups water, and 1/4 teaspoon salt to a boil in a 3- to 4-quart heavy saucepan, then reduce heat to low and simmer, covered with a tight-fitting lid, 45 minutes (rice will be cooked but still wet). Stir in sugar, a scant 1/4 teaspoon salt, and 1 1/2 cups coconut milk and bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to low and simmer, uncovered, stirring occasionally, until mixture is thick and rice is tender but still slightly chewy, about 30 minutes.', u'Remove from heat and cool to warm or room temperature, stirring occasionally, at least 30 minutes. Just before serving, stir pudding and divide among 8 bowls. Stir remaining coconut milk and drizzle over pudding.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/black-rice-pudding-233288', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 servings', 'recipe title': u'Black Rice Pudding', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This dense quickbread is traditionally baked in empty coffee cans.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'75%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 tablespoon butter plus more for serving, room temperature', u'2 cups whole milk', u'1/2 cup mild-flavored (light) molasses', u'1/4 cup (packed) light brown sugar', u'1 teaspoon kosher salt', u'1 1/4 cups whole wheat flour', u'1 cup all-purpose flour', u'1 cup rye flour', u'1/3 cup cornmeal', u'1 tablespoons baking soda', u'1 teaspoon baking powder', u'1 cup raisins (optional)', u'Special equipment: Two empty, clean 11-13-ounce coffee cans', u'Ingredient info: Rye flour is available at natural foods stores and some supermarkets.'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F. Cut two 6" squares of foil. Coat insides of cans and one side of foil squares with 1 tablespoon butter. Stir milk and next 3 ingredients in a small saucepan over low heat until sugar dissolves and mixture is just warmed (do not boil). Whisk whole wheat flour and next 5 ingredients in a large bowl. Add milk mixture; whisk until smooth. Fold in raisins, if using. Divide batter between cans. Smooth tops.', u'Cover cans with foil, butter side down. Secure foil with kitchen twine. Place cans foil side up in a deep roasting pan or a heavy shallow pot. Transfer pan to oven. Pour very hot water into pan to come about 3" up sides of cans.', u'Bake until a skewer inserted through foil into the center of each loaf comes out clean, about 1 1/2 hours. Transfer to a wire rack. Let cool for 10 minutes. Run a thin knife around edges of cans. Invert to release loaves onto rack. Let cool completely. DO AHEAD: Bread can be made 3 days ahead. Wrap tightly in plastic; store at room temperature.', u'Slice bread. Serve with soft butter.'], 'chef': u'Mary-Frances Heck', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/boston-brown-bread-51122630', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 10 servings ', 'recipe title': u'Boston Brown Bread', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'We used chef Fergus Henderson\'s technique for braising duck legs so the skin sides, peeking above the liquid like "alligators in a swamp," stay crisp while the meat braises.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'12 fresh duck legs (7 to 11 lb depending on amount of fat on legs)', u'2 lb shallots, peeled and, if very large, halved', u'4 lb parsnips, peeled and cut diagonally into 1-inch-thick slices (halve large slices lengthwise)', u'2 tablespoons minced garlic', u'1 1/2 tablespoons chopped fresh thyme or 1 teaspoon dried, crumbled', u'2 Turkish bay leaves or 1 halved California bay leaf', u'2 1/2 teaspoons salt', u'1 3/4 teaspoons black pepper', u'1/4 teaspoon ground allspice', u'2 cups dry white wine', u'6 to 8 cups chicken stock, homemade or store-bought (preferably not canned broth; 48 to 64 fl oz)', u'Special equipment: 2 (13- by 9- by 2-inch) baking pans', u'Garnish: fresh thyme sprigs'], 'preperation steps': [u'Put oven racks in upper and lower thirds of oven and preheat oven to 450\xb0F.', u'Trim fat and skin from sides of duck legs, leaving a covering of skin on top of legs (there may be fat underneath skin). Reserve 1/2 cup fat (for cooking). Score skin on legs in a 1/2-inch crosshatch pattern, cutting through fat but not into meat.', u'Coarsely chop reserved duck fat and heat in a 12-inch heavy skillet over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until melted. Remove from heat and discard any solids with a slotted spoon.', u'Divide shallots, parsnips, garlic, thyme, bay leaves, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1 teaspoon pepper between baking pans. Add 2 tablespoons rendered duck fat to each pan, reserving remainder in skillet, and toss to coat vegetables. Roast vegetables, turning occasionally and switching position of pans halfway through roasting, until browned in patches, 20 to 30 minutes total.', u'Pat duck legs dry. Stir together allspice, remaining 1 1/2 teaspoons salt, and remaining 3/4 teaspoon pepper in a small bowl and rub all over legs. Heat fat remaining in skillet over moderately high heat until hot but not smoking, then saut\xe9 4 duck legs, skin sides down, until well browned, 3 to 5 minutes. Turn legs over with tongs and saut\xe9 until undersides are browned, 2 minutes more. Transfer with tongs to paper towels to drain. Brown remaining duck legs (in batches of 4) in same manner, pouring off all but 2 tablespoons fat from skillet between batches.', u'Reduce oven temperature to 375\xb0F.', u'Divide duck legs between baking pans, nestling them, skin sides up, in vegetables. Add wine and just enough stock so that most of each leg is submerged but skins are not.', u'Braise duck and vegetables, uncovered, switching position of pans halfway through braising, until duck is tender, 1 1/2 to 2 hours total.', u'Transfer vegetables and duck with a slotted spoon to a platter. Skim fat from pan juices and serve juices, seasoned with salt and pepper if necessary, on the side.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/braised-duck-legs-with-shallots-and-parsnips-109109', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 12 servings', 'recipe title': u'Braised Duck Legs with Shallots and Parsnips', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This recipe serves 4 as a main course after you set aside half of the veal shanks and sauce to make Eggplant and Veal Pastitsio . Otherwise it serves 8.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'89%', 'ingredient list': [u'8 (12- to 14-oz) meaty cross-cut veal shanks (also known as ossobuco; each about 13/4 inches thick)', u'3/4 cup all-purpose flour', u'3 1/2 teaspoons salt', u'1 1/4 teaspoons black pepper', u'6 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil', u'1 large onion, chopped (2 cups)', u'4 large garlic cloves, finely chopped', u'5 anchovy fillets, rinsed, patted dry, and finely chopped', u'2 Turkish bay leaves or 1 California', u'1 cup dry white wine', u'1 (28-oz) can whole tomatoes in juice, pulsed (including juice) in food processor until chopped', u'1 cup water', u'2 (4- by 1-inch) strips fresh lemon zest', u'2 (4- by 1-inch) strips fresh orange zest', u'1/4 cup finely chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley', u'1 teaspoon finely grated fresh lemon zest', u'1 teaspoon finely grated fresh orange zest', u'1 large garlic clove, minced'], 'preperation steps': [u'Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 350\xb0F.', u'Pat shanks dry. Stir together flour, 2 teaspoons salt, and 1 teaspoon pepper on a sheet of wax paper. Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a 12-inch heavy skillet over moderately high heat until hot but not smoking. While oil heats, dredge 4 shanks in flour mixture, shaking off excess. Brown shanks in oil on all sides, turning with tongs, about 8 to 10 minutes. Transfer to a large (17- by 12- by 2-inch) roasting pan. Add 2 tablespoons oil to skillet and repeat with remaining 4 shanks. Discard remaining flour mixture.', u'Add remaining 2 tablespoons oil to skillet and cook onion, garlic, anchovies, bay leaves, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon pepper over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until onion is softened, 6 to 8 minutes. Add wine and boil, scraping up any brown bits, until reduced by half, about 2 minutes. Stir in tomatoes, water, zest strips, and remaining teaspoon salt and bring to a boil, then pour mixture over shanks. Tightly cover pan with foil and braise in oven 1 hour. Turn shanks over, cover, and continue to braise until meat is very tender, about 1 1/2 hours more.', u'Remove from oven and skim fat from surface of sauce, then transfer shanks and sauce to a large platter. Discard bay leaves.', u'Stir together parsley, grated zests, and garlic and sprinkle over shanks.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/braised-veal-shanks-232803', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 4 to 8 servings', 'recipe title': u'Braised Veal Shanks', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'In 2006, I packed up my gear and traveled to the Mall of America for the Food Network Pizza Champions Challenge. Over the course of a very grueling day, we competed for three Guinness World Records in front of a big audience and a panel of famous judges. I won two of the world-record rounds: Biggest Pizza Continuously Spinning for Two Minutes, and Most Consecutive Rolls Across the Shoulders in 30 Seconds.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 (13-ounce/370-gram) ball Master Dough , preferably with starter made with Poolish', u'1 cup (255 grams) balsamic vinegar', u'3 parts flour mixed with 1 part semolina, for dusting', u'2-ounce (55-gram) piece Asiago cheese, cold, for shaving', u'6 ounces (170 grams) whole-milk mozzarella cheese, shredded (1-1/2 cups)', u'1-1/2 ounces (45 grams) Gorgonzola cheese, broken into small pieces', u'2 to 3 tablespoons (40-60 grams) fig jam, preferably Dalmatia brand', u'3 ounces (85 grams) thinly sliced prosciutto (about 6 slices)', u'2 pizza baking stones or steels, pizza peel'], 'preperation steps': [u'Remove the dough ball from the refrigerator and leave wrapped at room temperature until the dough warms to 60\xb0F to 65\xb0F. Meanwhile, set up the oven with two pizza stones or baking steels and preheat to 500\xb0F for 1 hour.', u'Meanwhile, put the vinegar in a small, heavy saucepan over medium heat. Once steam is rising from the surface, reduce the heat to the lowest setting to keep the vinegar below a simmer. No bubbles should break through the surface. If the lowest setting is still too hot, place the pan over a diffuser. Once the vinegar has reduced by three-fourths, remove it from the heat. The glaze can be stored in a covered container at room temperature for several months.', u'Dust the work surface with the dusting mixture, then move the dough to the surface and dust the top.', u'Sprinkle a wooden peel with the dusting mixture.', u'Roll out the dough into a round 15 inches in diameter. Using a pizza wheel, trim the dough to a 13-inch round, flatten the edge, then dock the surface of the dough.', u"Move the dough to the peel. As you work, shake the peel forward and backward to ensure the dough isn't sticking.", u'Using a vegetable peeler, shave the Asiago over the surface of the dough, leaving a 3/4-inch border. Mound the mozzarella in the center of the pizza and use your fingertips to spread it out evenly over the Asiago.', u'Slide the pizza onto the top stone.', u'Bake for 7 minutes. Lift the pizza onto the peel and distribute the Gorgonzola pieces evenly over the top. Rotate the pizza 180 degrees, transfer it to the bottom stone, and bake for 3 to 4 minutes, until the bottom is browned and crisp and the top is golden brown.', u'Transfer the pizza to a cutting board and cut into 6 wedges. Spoon small dollops of fig jam (about 1/4 teaspoon each) around the pizza. Tear the prosciutto slices lengthwise into 2 or 3 strips and drape the pieces over the pizza slices. To finish, squeeze a thin spiral of balsamic glaze onto the pizza.'], 'chef': u'Tony Gemignani', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/cal-italia-pizza-with-prosciutto-and-figs-51255840', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes one 13-inch pizza; 6 slices', 'recipe title': u'Cal-Italia Pizza with Prosciutto and Figs', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': None, 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'3 large grapefruits', u'13 cups cold water', u'4 cups sugar', u'3 tablespoons light corn syrup'], 'preperation steps': [u'Quarter the grapefruits lengthwise and remove the pulp, reserving it for another use. Scrape as much of the pith from the rind as possible with a spoon, cut the pieces of zest in half crosswise, and cut them lengthwise into 1/4-inch-wide strips. In a kettle cover the zest with 4 cups of the water, bring the water to a boil, and simmer the zest for 10 minutes. Drain the zest, refresh it under cold water, and repeat the simmering, draining, and refreshing process 2 more times. Sprinkle each of 2 jelly-roll pans with 1 cup of the sugar. In the kettle combine the remaining 2 cups sugar, the remaining 1 cup water, and the corn syrup and boil the mixture, washing down any sugar crystals clinging to the side with a brush dipped in cold water, for 3 minutes. Stir in the zest and simmer it, stirring occasionally, for 15 minutes, or until the syrup is thickened. Continue to simmer the syrup, stirring constantly and being careful not to let it burn, until a candy thermometer registers 230\xb0F. Transfer the zest with a fork to the prepared pans, roll it in the sugar to coat it well, separating the strips, and let it cool. Transfer the zest to racks and let it dry for at least 4 hours or overnight. The candied zest keeps, separated by sheets of wax paper in an airtight container lined with wax paper, at room temperature for 2 weeks or chilled for 1 month.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/candied-grapefruit-zest-13544', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes about 4 cups', 'recipe title': u'Candied Grapefruit Zest', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Active time: 1 3/4 hr Start to finish: 2 3/4 hr (includes making pastry shell)', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'73%', 'ingredient list': [u'4 cups fresh kumquats (1 1/2 lb with leaves; 1 lb without)', u'1 cup water', u'2 cups plus 2 tablespoons sugar', u'1 teaspoon fennel seeds, lightly toasted', u'2/3 cup ricotta', u'1/3 cup sour cream', u'1 (12- to 13-inch) baked sweet tart shell', u'Special equipment: an electric coffee/spice grinder'], 'preperation steps': [u'Thinly slice kumquats crosswise with a sharp knife, discarding seeds.', u'Bring water and 2 cups sugar to a boil in a 2-quart heavy saucepan, stirring until sugar is dissolved, then simmer syrup, uncovered, 5 minutes. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'If you choose to bake only one cookie from this collection, make it these bites. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Nick Malgieri, the director of baking and pastry programs at The Institute of Culinary Education in New York City, created this recipe exclusively for Epicurious. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u"A caldin is a coconut curry, typical of Goa. Though caldins are made with fresh coconut milk in India, chef Cardoz uses Chaokoh brand canned unsweetened coconut milk. It's thicker and richer than other brands, and imparts a great deal of flavor. It's important not to let the caldin boil during cooking, or the coconut sauce will break.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 heavy coconut (without any cracks and containing liquid)', u'3 garlic cloves', u'1 small onion, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced lengthwise', u'2 1/2 cups plus 2 tablespoons water', u'1 tablespoon vegetable oil', u'1 tablespoon cumin seeds, ground in an electric coffee/spice grinder', u'1 teaspoon turmeric', u'1 (4-inch) fresh red chile, halved lengthwise, keeping stem intact', u'1 large head cauliflower (2 1/2 pounds), cut into 1-inch-wide florets', u'1/2 pound medium shrimp (31 to 35 per pound), peeled, leaving tail and first segment of shell intact, and deveined', u'1 1/2 teaspoons salt', u'1 (1-inch) piece tamarind from a pliable block*', u'1 (13- to 14-ounce) can unsweetened coconut milk* (preferably Chaokoh brand)', u'1 tablespoon cider vinegar', u'Accompaniment: steamed basmati rice'], 'preperation steps': [u'Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 400\xb0F.', u'Pierce softest eye of coconut with a metal skewer or small screwdriver and drain liquid. Remove brown membrane with a sharp paring knife or vegetable peeler.', u'Coarsely chop one third of coconut (reserve remainder for another use) and finely grind in a blender. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This is a mostly hands-off dinner that only needs a salad of assertive greens as accompaniment. The chicken gets a head start in the oven, but then finishes up by sharing its pan with the couscous. This way, the pasta laps up flavor from the meat, while getting crispy on top, and in turn, the steam coming up from the couscous keeps the chicken incredibly juicy. An intense slurry of anchovies, garlic, and lemon makes up most of the piquant dressing, with bursts of contrasting sweetness from the raisins.', 'rating': u'0/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 whole chicken, about 4 pounds', u'1 tablespoon butter, softened', u'Medium-grain kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper', u'1 lemon', u'Approximately 2.5 cups chicken stock or water', u'4 cloves garlic, with loose paper removed but unpeeled', u'8 ounces large pearl couscous (see Note)', u"1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil (it needn't be an expensive one but should taste good)", u'2 to 4 anchovy fillets, rinsed if salt-packed', u'Generous pinch of crushed red pepper flakes', u'1 1/2 tablespoons capers, rinsed if packed in salt, drained if packed in brine', u'2 tablespoons golden raisins or dried currants', u'A couple of handfuls of flat-leaf parsley, chopped', u'Pickled caperberries, for garnish (optional)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat an oven to 400\xb0F with a baking pan on the lower middle rack.', u'Pat the chicken dry with paper towels. Rub the butter all over the chicken, making sure to give the back a good coating. Season generously with salt and pepper, inside and out. Position the wing tips behind the back and tie the legs together. Place the chicken, breast side up, on the preheated pan. Roast for 30 minutes.', u'Meanwhile, stir the juice from 1/2 lemon into the stock in a small saucepan. Heat over medium-low heat until steaming, then pop in the garlic. Pull from the heat and keep in a warm spot. (I leave it on top of the hot stove, but with the burner off.) After 30 minutes are up for the chicken, pour 1 cup of the liquid into the baking pan, holding back the garlic, and roast for 30 minutes more.', u'Cut the juiced lemon half into wedges; keep the other half for the relish.', u'Pull the baking pan from the oven. Sprinkle the couscous around the chicken. Pour the remaining liquid onto the couscous and tuck in the lemon wedges and soaked garlic. Return the baking pan to the oven and continue to roast until both the chicken and the couscous are cooked through, around 30 minutes. If the liquid is absorbed before the couscous is cooked, add more liquid, a half cup at a time, as needed.', u"Let the baking pan stand for 10 minutes while you make the relish. Squeeze the (now) roasted garlic into a small skillet. Add the oil and set the pan over medium heat. When the oil is hot, add the anchovies and red pepper flakes. Cook, stirring and breaking up the anchovies and garlic, until they've turned into a grungy paste, 2 to 3 minutes. Add the capers to the pan, and cook for 1 minute more. Stir in the juice from the second half of the lemon, along with the raisins and half of the parsley. Reduce the heat and simmer for 2 minutes, then check for seasoning. Remove the chicken to a board and carve as you'd like. Fluff the couscous with a fork, then arrange the cut chicken on top. Scatter the rest of the parsley over the whole baking pan of chicken and couscous, and serve with the relish."], 'chef': u"a O'Brady", 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/chicken-and-couscous-with-a-punchy-relish-56389470', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 4, generously ', 'recipe title': u'Chicken and Couscous with a Punchy Relish', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"The coffee foam attains its consistency with the help of a charged siphon. If you don't own one, don't worry\u2014the coffee mixture can also be served, chilled but unfoamed, as a sauce.", 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'1/2 cup green coffee beans', u'1/4 cup packed light brown sugar', u'1 (13 1/2-oz) can unsweetened coconut milk', u'1/2 cup heavy cream', u'4 whole large eggs', u'4 large egg yolks', u'1/2 cup granulated sugar', u'1/2 lb Valrhona or Lindt bittersweet chocolate (not unsweetened), chopped', u'2 sticks (1 cup) unsalted butter, cut into pieces', u'1/2 cup cake flour (not self-rising)', u'Special equipment: 1-liter whipped-cream siphon and 2 gas (N2O) chargers'], 'preperation steps': [u'Toast coffee beans with brown sugar in a 2-quart heavy saucepan over moderately low heat, stirring constantly to evenly toast beans, until sugar is melted and beans are color of almond skins, 12 to 15 minutes.', u'Add coconut milk and simmer (mixture will bubble up and steam, and sugar will harden), stirring occasionally, until sugar is dissolved, about 5 minutes. Unscrew charge holder from head and put in a charger. Reattach charge holder and screw on tightly. Gas will be released into siphon (with a whooshing sound) within a few seconds. Chill filled siphon at least 1 hour to produce a stiffer foam. Remove and discard first charger. (As you unscrew charge holder, you\u2019ll hear a brief hissing sound.) If fitting from holder comes out attached to charger, just remove charger and reattach fitting. Screw on second charger and chill at least 15 minutes (longer if a test of foam is not thick enough).', u'Preheat oven to 400\xb0F. Butter and flour 8 (4-oz) ramekins, knocking out excess flour, and put on a baking sheet.', u'Whisk together whole eggs, yolks, and sugar until combined well.', u'Melt chocolate and butter in a double boiler or a metal bowl set over a saucepan of simmering water, stirring.', u'Remove top of double boiler or bowl from heat and whisk egg mixture into it. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Nick Malgieri, the director of baking and pastry programs at The Institute of Culinary Education in New York City, created this recipe exclusively for Epicurious. The enriched yeast dough is a snap to make and even easier to shape into decadent, delicious cinnamon rolls. Best of all, the rolls can be baked ahead and reheated for a fresh-from-the-oven breakfast treat. For more on cinnamon rolls, including tips from Malgieri, see Classic Recipes: Cinnamon Rolls.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'56%', 'ingredient list': [u'2/3 cup whole milk', u'2 (1/4-ounce) envelopes instant yeast (4 teaspoons total)', u'1/2 cup sugar', u'2 large eggs, at room temperature', u'3 cups unbleached bread flour', u'1 teaspoon fine sea salt or table salt', u'4 tablespoons (1/2 stick) unsalted butter, cut into 6 pieces and softened at room temperature', u'8 tablespoons (1 stick) unsalted butter, cut into small pieces and softened at room temperature, plus additional butter for greasing the pan and plastic wrap', u'3/4 cup packed light brown sugar', u'1 tablespoon ground cinnamon', u'2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract', u'2 tablespoons unsalted butter', u"1 cup confectioners' sugar, sifted after measuring", u'Special equipment: Instant-read thermometer, stand mixer fitted with a dough hook, 13- by 9-inch metal baking pan, parchment paper or foil'], 'preperation steps': [u'In a heavy, small saucepan over moderate heat, warm the milk until it almost reaches a boil. Remove the pan from the heat and let the milk cool to lukewarm (about 100\xb0F).', u'In the bowl of a stand mixer, whisk together the lukewarm milk and yeast. Wait 30 seconds, then whisk again. Add the sugar and eggs and whisk to combine. Add the flour and salt and use a rubber spatula to stir together. Scrape the bowl to make sure there is no unabsorbed flour clinging to the sides or at the bottom of the bowl. Distribute the butter pieces on the surface of the dough, then place the bowl on the mixer and attach the dough hook.', u"With the mixer on low, knead the dough until it comes together, about 2 minutes. Using a rubber spatula, scrape the dough off the hook and from the bottom and sides of the bowl. With the mixer on medium, knead the dough until it's smooth and elastic, about 1 minute. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let the dough rest at warm room temperature for 1 hour. (The dough won't double in size, but may look slightly puffy.)", u'In a medium bowl, use a rubber spatula to beat the butter until smooth. Add the brown sugar, cinnamon, and vanilla and beat until smooth and fully combined. Make sure the mixture is easily spreadable, and beat it a little longer if it seems too firm.', u'Line a 13- by 9-inch metal baking pan with parchment paper or foil, allowing 1 to 2 inches to hang over the long ends of the pan. Butter the parchment or foil.', u'Lightly flour a work surface and scrape the dough out of the bowl. Lightly flour the dough then gently press and pull it into a 12- by 18-inch rectangle. Dot the cinnamon butter all over the surface, then use a knife or small offset spatula to evenly spread it over the entire surface of the dough.', u'Starting at one of the 18-inch-long edges, roll up the dough, jellyroll-style. After rolling, push and gently squeeze the roll together to make it 18 inches long. Use a sharp knife to cut the roll into 12 (1 1/2-inch-thick) slices. One at a time, work the slices into an even round shape (they squish when cut) and arrange them, cut side down and about 1 inch apart on all sides, in the prepared pan, in 4 rows of 3 rolls. Cover the pan with buttered plastic wrap and let the rolls proof at warm room temperature until they are puffed and starting to fill the spaces in between them, 1 to 2 hours depending on the room temperature (the warmer the kitchen, the faster the rolls will proof).', u'Once you see the rolls puffing visibly, set a rack in the middle of the oven and preheat to 400\xb0F. Place the pan in the oven, decrease the temperature to 375\xb0F, and bake the rolls until they are well-risen and golden, about 25 minutes.', u'Cool the rolls in the pan on a rack for 10 minutes. Using the parchment paper or foil overhang, lift the rolls out of the pan and transfer to a work surface. DO AHEAD: Cinnamon rolls can be baked, cooled, and stored in an airtight container, up to 2 days. Warm the cinnamon rolls in a 350\xb0F oven for about 10 minutes then ice them as described below. Cinnamon rolls can also be frozen: Once cool, return the cinnamon rolls, still on the parchment or foil, to the pan, wrap the pan in a double layer of foil, and freeze up to 2 weeks. Defrost the rolls then warm them in a 350\xb0F oven for about 10 minutes, ice, and serve.', u"In a small saucepan over low heat, warm the butter and 2 tablespoons water, stirring occasionally, until the butter is melted and the liquid is gently simmering. Remove the pan from the heat, add the confectioners' sugar, and use a small rubber spatula to stir the icing until it's thick and creamy.", u'Using a small spoon, drizzle about a tablespoon of the icing in the center of each roll and use the back of the spoon to spread the icing over the tops of the rolls. Let the icing set for about 10 minutes, then separate and serve the rolls.'], 'chef': u'Nick Malgieri', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/cinnamon-rolls-with-icing-51160400', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 12 cinnamon rolls', 'recipe title': u'Cinnamon Rolls with Icing', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This sweet-savory condiment is delicious with roasted or grilled meats.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 tablespoons yellow mustard seeds (3/4 to 1 ounce)', u'3 3/4 pounds firm but ripe plums, halved, pitted, cut into 1/4-inch-thick slices', u'2 cups (packed) golden brown sugar (13 to 14 ounces)', u'2 cups distilled white vinegar', u'1/2 small white onion, halved, cut into 1/4-inch-thick slices (about 1/2 cup)', u'5 cinnamon sticks, broken into 1- to 1 1/2-inch pieces', u'1 tablespoon coarse kosher salt'], 'preperation steps': [u'Stir mustard seeds in small dry skillet over medium heat until seeds darken slightly and begin to pop, about 5 minutes. Increase heat to medium-high and bring to boil. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer until liquid is thick and syrupy and mixture is reduced to 7 cups, stirring frequently, about 55 minutes.', u'Ladle mixture into 7 hot clean 1/2-pint glass canning jars, leaving 1/2-inch space at top of jars. Remove air bubbles. Wipe jar threads and rims with clean damp cloth. Cover with hot lids; apply screw bands. Process jars in pot of boiling water 15 minutes. Cool jars completely. Store in cool dark place up to 1 year.'], 'chef': u'Jill Silverman Hough', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/cinnamon-plum-chutney-350118', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes about seven 1/2-pint jars', 'recipe title': u'Cinnamon-Plum Chutney', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Sage is to turkey what cinnamon is to apples; they go together like bread and butter. The seasoned butter on this bird is a bright and herbal mix of chopped sage leaves and fresh orange and lemon zest, which bathes the breast with the essence of the Thanksgiving aroma.', 'rating': u'0/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'0%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 (13- to 15-pound) turkey at room temperature 1 hour, any feathers and quills removed with tweezers or needle-nose pliers, and neck and giblets removed and reserved for giblet stock or another use if desired', u'1 stick (1/2 cup) unsalted butter, well softened', u'1/4 cup finely chopped fresh sage leaves', u'1 teaspoon grated lemon zest', u'Salt', u'Freshly ground black pepper', u'1 navel orange', u'1 medium red onion, cut into wedges', u'3 to 4 cups brown turkey stock, giblet stock, or low-sodium chicken broth', u'1/2 stick (1/4 cup) unsalted butter', u'6 tablespoons all-purpose flour', u'Salt', u'Freshly ground black pepper', u'Special equipment: 2 small metal skewers; kitchen string; large flameproof roasting pan (not glass) with a flat rack; instant-read thermometer; 2-quart glass measure'], 'preperation steps': [u'Heat oven to 425\xb0F with rack in lowest position. Discard any excess fat from inside turkey cavity. Pat dry inside and out.', u'Stir together butter, sage, lemon zest, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper in a small bowl. Grate enough zest from orange to measure 1 teaspoon and add to butter mixture. Quarter orange lengthwise and reserve.', u'Starting at (smaller) neck cavity, gently slide an index finger between skin and flesh of breast to loosen skin (be careful not to tear skin). Push butter mixture evenly under skin on both sides of breast, and rub skin from outside to distribute butter evenly.', u'Sprinkle 1 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper in turkey cavities.', u'Stuff neck cavity (smaller cavity) with a few orange and onion wedges, then fold neck skin under body and secure with metal skewers.', u'Stuff larger cavity with remaining onion and orange wedges, then tie drumsticks together with kitchen string and tuck wings under body.', u"Put turkey on rack in roasting pan and sprinkle skin all over with 1 1/2 teaspoons salt (if you are using a kosher turkey, see the Cooks' note) and 1/2 teaspoon pepper. Add 1 cup water to pan and roast turkey 30 minutes at 425\xb0F.", u'Reduce oven temperature to 350\xb0F. Rotate turkey 180 degrees and roast 30 minutes. Rotate turkey again 180 degrees and baste with pan juices. Tent turkey loosely with foil and continue to roast, rotating and basting with juices every 30 minutes (if pan becomes completely dry, add 1/2 cup water) until an instant-read thermometer inserted into fleshy part of thighs and thickest part of breasts (test both sides, close to but not touching bone) registers at least 165\xb0F, about 1 1/2 to 2 hours more. (Total roasting time will be 2 1/2 to 3 hours.)', u'Carefully tilt turkey so juices in large cavity run into pan. Transfer turkey to a platter, reserving juices in pan. Let turkey stand, uncovered, 30 minutes. Discard onions and oranges from large cavity and wait to discard onions and oranges in smaller cavity until they are accessible during carving.', u'Pour pan juices through a fine-mesh sieve into 2-quart glass measure (do not clean roasting pan), then skim off and discard fat. (If using a fat separator, pour pan juices through sieve into separator and let stand until fat rises to top, 1 to 2 minutes. Carefully pour pan juices from separator into measure, discarding fat.)', u'Position roasting pan across 2 burners, then add 1 cup water and deglaze roasting pan by boiling over high heat, stirring and scraping up brown bits, 1 minute. Pour through sieve into measure containing pan juices. Add enough turkey stock to pan juices to bring total to 4 cups (if stock is congealed, heat to liquefy).', u'Melt butter in a 3-quart heavy saucepan over medium-low heat and whisk in flour. Cook roux, whisking, 3 minutes. Add stock mixture in a stream, whisking constantly to prevent lumps, then bring to a boil, whisking occasionally. Stir in any turkey juices accumulated on platter and simmer, stirring occasionally, 5 minutes. Season gravy with salt and pepper.'], 'chef': u'Gina Marie Miraglia Eriquez', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/citrus-sage-roast-turkey-with-gravy-large-crowd-51137800', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 to 10 servings', 'recipe title': u'Citrus-Sage Roast Turkey with Gravy: Large Crowd', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': None, 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'89%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 1/2 teaspoons instant-espresso powder', u'3 tablespoons water', u'2/3 cup plus 1/2 cup sugar', u'1 (13- to 14-oz) can unsweetened coconut milk, stirred well', u'1 1/4 cups whole milk', u'3 whole large eggs', u'2 large egg yolks', u'1/8 teaspoon salt', u'Special equipment: 6 (6-oz) ramekins'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 325\xb0F.', u'Stir together espresso powder and water until powder is dissolved.', u'Cook 1/2 cup sugar with a pinch of salt in a 1 1/2- to 2-quart heavy saucepan over moderate heat, undisturbed, until it begins to melt. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'We imagine that biting into a cloud would be a lot like savoring a mouthful of this mousse, which dissolves gently into traces of coconut on the tongue. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Made from yuca (pronounced "YOO-ca"), pearl tapioca can be found at Asian markets and specialty foods shops.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'8 1/4 cups water', u'2/3 cup large (3/4- to 1/4-inch) pearl tapioca (not quick-cooking)', u'1/2 cup grated or crumbled dark palm sugar (4 oz)*', u'2 (13- to 14-oz) cans unsweetened coconut milk (do not shake)', u'2 firm-ripe mangoes (1 1/2 lb total), peeled, pitted, and cut into 1/4-inch pieces', u'1 lb firm-ripe papaya (preferably red), peeled, seeded, and cut into 1/4-inch pieces', u'1/2 pineapple, peeled, cored, and cut into 1/4-inch pieces', u'2 cups shaved ice', u'Garnish: fresh coconut shavings, toasted', u'Special equipment: an ice shaver, preferably manual'], 'preperation steps': [u'Bring 8 cups water to a boil in a 2-quart saucepan and add tapioca, stirring constantly. Simmer syrup until slightly thickened, about 5 minutes.', u'Scoop out 3/4 cup (total) of thick layer of coconut cream from tops of cans (reserving remainder for another use) and whisk into syrup until combined well. Chill syrup until cold, about 1 hour.', u'Add 3 cups cold water to translucent tapioca, then drain in a sieve. (This removes excess starch.)', u'Spoon 3 tablespoons syrup into each of 4 glasses (there will be some left over), then divide fruit and tapioca among them. Top with shaved ice.', u'*Available at Asian markets and Uwajimaya (800-889-1928).'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/coconut-and-palm-sugar-syrup-with-tapioca-tropical-fruit-and-shaved-ice-105432', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 4 servings', 'recipe title': u'Coconut and Palm Sugar Syrup with Tapioca, Tropical Fruit, and Shaved Ice', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Roasting the garlic mellows the flavor, which results in an aioli that is less pungent than traditional ones. Besides enhancing the taste of Cornish hens, this makes a perfect accompaniment to vegetables, lamb, and fish, and it's great as a dip.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 whole heads of garlic', u'2 teaspoons extra-virgin olive oil', u'2 Cornish hens (1 1/4 to 1 1/2 lb each), rinsed and patted dry', u'1 1/2 teaspoons salt', u'1/2 teaspoon black pepper', u'1 cup bottled mayonnaise', u'2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice', u'1 teaspoon finely grated fresh lemon zest', u'2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh chives', u'Special equipment: kitchen string; a small (13- by 9-inch) roasting pan; an instant-read thermometer'], 'preperation steps': [u'Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 500\xb0F.', u'Trim off and discard about 1/4 inch from top of garlic heads to expose cloves, then put heads on a sheet of foil. Tie legs together with string and tuck wing tips under. Transfer to roasting pan and roast alongside garlic until hens are golden brown and thermometer registers 170\xb0F when inserted into leg joint, 30 to 40 minutes. Let stand, loosely covered with foil, 15 minutes.', u'Unwrap garlic carefully and cool slightly, then squeeze pulp into a bowl. Add remaining ingredients (including salt and pepper plus 2 tablespoons pan juices from hens if desired) and stir until combined well.', u'Halve hens lengthwise. Serve with aioli.'], 'chef': u'Paul Grimes', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/cornish-hens-with-roasted-garlic-aioli-234989', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 4 servings', 'recipe title': u'Cornish Hens with Roasted-Garlic A\xefoli', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This impressive dessert is the sum of many parts that can each be made several days in advance. Assemble the trifle the day before serving to allow the cake to absorb the custard and the flavors to fully develop.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'88%', 'ingredient list': [u'12 large egg yolks', u'2 1/4 cups sugar', u'6 tablespoons whole milk', u'1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla', u'1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour', u'3/4 teaspoon salt', u'6 large egg whites', u'Cranberry jam', u'Cognac syrup<epi:recipelink></epi:recipelink>', u'Rich custard<epi:recipelink></epi:recipelink>', u'1 1/3 cups chilled heavy cream', u'1/4 cup confectioners sugar', u'2 tablespoons Cognac or other brandy', u'1/4 teaspoon vanilla', u'Garnish: sugared cranberries and mint leaves', u'Special equipment: 3 (15- by 10- by 1/2-inch) baking pans and a 3 1/2-quart straight-sided glass trifle or souffl\xe9 dish'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F and butter pans. Line bottom of each pan with wax or parchment paper and butter paper. Dust pans with flour, knocking out excess.', u'Whisk together yolks, 1 1/2 cups sugar, milk, and vanilla in a large bowl until combined well, then whisk in flour and salt until smooth. (Batter will be thick.)', u'Beat whites with an electric mixer until they hold soft peaks. With mixer at low speed, gradually beat in remaining 3/4 cup sugar. Increase speed to high and beat until whites hold stiff, glossy peaks.', u'Fold about one third of whites into batter to lighten, then fold in remaining whites gently but thoroughly.', u'Divide batter among pans and spread evenly. Rap pans against a work surface to release any air bubbles. Bake, 1 pan at a time, in middle of oven until cake is pale golden and beginning to shrink around edges, 10 to 11 minutes per pan. Cool layers completely in pans on racks.', u'Loosen edges of 1 cake layer with a knife. Place a sheet of wax or parchment paper on top of layer and invert onto a rack. Carefully peel paper from cake. Place a new sheet of wax or parchment paper on inverted cake and reinvert onto work surface, peeling off paper that is now on top. Repeat with remaining 2 layers.', u'With long side of layers toward you, halve layers vertically with a serrated knife. Spread 1 half of each layer (3 of 6 halves) with cranberry jam, then top with remaining plain halves.', u'Put each "sandwich" crosswise into 10 (71/2- by 3/4-inch) strips. Arrange 1 strip vertically in trifle dish with a cut side against glass (see photo below), then trim strip flush with top of dish. Using trimmed piece as a guide, cut remaining strips to fit dish, reserving trimmings. Brush strips on all sides with Cognac syrup and fit strips tightly all around edge of dish. (If your dish is slightly smaller on bottom than on top, cut a few strips in half diagonally to fill any gaps.)', u'Brush trimmings with syrup and arrange one fourth of them in 1 layer in bottom of dish. Pour in 1 cup custard. Repeat layering of trimmings and custard to fill dish, ending with custard. (You may have a small amount of custard left over.) Brush top of strips around edge with syrup. Cover trifle with plastic wrap and chill at least 8 hours.', u'Beat heavy cream with confectioners sugar, Cognac, and vanilla with an electric mixer until it holds soft peaks. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This lovely first course has the texture of risotto without the constant stirring. {'cook_time': None, 'description': None, 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'73%', 'ingredient list': [u'3 cups fresh blueberries or frozen, thawed (13 to 14 ounces), divided', u'2/3 cup (packed) golden brown sugar', u'2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice', u'1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon peel', u'Pinch of salt'], 'preperation steps': [u'Combine 11/2 cups blueberries and all remaining ingredients in medium saucepan.
