Using slotted spoon, transfer sage to paper towels to drain (leaves will darken slightly as they cool). Sprinkle lightly with salt. Set aside.', u'Cook potatoes in large pot of boiling salted water until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain well. Return potatoes to pot. Add butter and 1 1/3 cups milk; mash until smooth, thinning with milk if desired. Stir in dried sage. Season with salt and pepper.', u'Transfer potatoes to large bowl. Garnish with a few fried sage leaves; serve remaining fried sage leaves alongside.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/mashed-yukon-gold-potatoes-with-fried-sage-leaves-107501', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 servings', 'recipe title': u'Mashed Yukon Gold Potatoes with Fried Sage Leaves', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"This is what I'd call the quintessential American pizza dough, inspired by New York-style pizza: medium thin, satisfyingly chewy, and the ideal companion to mozzarella, tomato sauce, and the pizza toppings Americans love best, from pepperoni and sausage to olives, mushrooms, and other vegetables. It's the dough I teach first to new students, and the one I recommend experimenting with because it's so versatile and user-friendly.", 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'2.2 grams (3/4 teaspoon) active dry yeast', u'70 grams (1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon) warm water (80\xb0F to 85\xb0F)', u"453 grams flour (3 1/2 cups) with 13 to 14 percent protein, preferably All Trumps, Pendleton Flour Mills Power, Giusto's High Performer, King Arthur Sir Lancelot Unbleached Hi-Gluten, or Tony's California Artisan Flour", u'10 grams (1 tablespoon plus 1/4 teaspoon) diastatic malt', u'210 grams (3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons) ice water, plus more as needed', u'90 grams Poolish or Tiga', u'10 grams (2 teaspoons) fine sea salt', u'5 grams (1 teaspoon) extra virgin olive oil'], 'preperation steps': [u'Put the yeast in a small bowl, add the warm water, and whisk vigorously for 30 seconds. The yeast should dissolve in the water and the mixture should foam. If it doesn\'t and the yeast granules float, the yeast is "dead" and should be discarded. Begin again with a fresh amount of yeast and water.', u'Combine the flour and malt in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook.', u'With the mixer running on the lowest speed, pour in most of the icewater, reserving about 2 tablespoons, followed by the yeast-water mixture. Pour the reserved water into the yeast bowl, swirl it around to dislodge any bits of yeast stuck to the bowl, and add to the mixer. Mix for about 15 seconds, stop the mixer, and add the poolish or tiga.', u"Continue to mix the dough at the lowest speed for about 1 minute, until most of the dough comes together around the hook. Stop the mixer. Use your fingers to pull away any dough clinging to the hook, and scrape the sides and bottom of the bowl with a bowl scraper or rubber spatula. Check the bottom of the bowl for any unincorporated flour. Turn the dough over and press it into the bottom of the bowl to pick up any stray pieces. If the dough isn't holding together, add small amounts of water (about 1/2 teaspoon to start) and mix until the dough is no longer dry and holds together.", u'Add the salt and mix on the lowest speed for 1 minute to combine.', u"Stop the mixer, pull the dough off the hook, and add the oil. Mix the dough for 1 to 2 minutes, stopping the mixer from time to time to pull the dough off the hook and scrape down the sides of the bowl, until all of the oil is absorbed. The dough won't look completely smooth.", u'Use a bowl scraper to transfer the dough to an unfloured work surface, then knead it for 2 to 3 minutes, until smooth. Cover the dough with a damp dish towel and let rest at room temperature for 20 minutes. Use the dough cutter to loosen the dough and to cut it in half. Weigh the dough, adjusting the quantity as necessary to give you two 13-ounce pieces. Form each piece into a ball. Any remaining dough can be discarded.', u'Form the dough into balls. Set the balls on a half sheet pan, spacing them about 3 inches apart. Or, if you will be baking the balls on different days, place each ball on a quarter sheet pan. Wrap the pan(s) airtight with a double layer of plastic wrap, sealing the wrap well under the pan(s). Put the pan(s) in a level spot in the refrigerator and refrigerate for 24 to 48 hours.'], 'chef': u'Tony Gemignani', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/master-dough-with-starter-51255340', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': None, 'recipe title': u'Master Dough with Starter', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This delicious tart has a buttery shortbread crust, a rich hazelnut-caramel filling, a creamy espresso-chocolate topping, and a sprinkling of crunchy cacao nibs (pieces of roasted cacao beans).', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': u'Per serving: 502.3 kcal calories, 59.0% calories from fat, 32.9 g fat, 17.5 g saturated fat, 68.6 mg cholesterol, 50.2 g carbohydrates, 2.0 g dietary fiber, 34.0 g total sugars, 48.2 g net carbohydrates, 4.9 g protein\n\nNutritional analysis provided by Bon App\xe9tit', 'recommendation': u'88%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 1/4 cups unbleached all purpose flour', u'1/3 cup powdered sugar', u'1/4 teaspoon salt', u'1/2 cup (1 stick) chilled unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes', u'1 tablespoon (or more) ice water', u'3/4 cup sugar', u'1/4 cup water', u'1/3 cup heavy whipping cream', u'2 tablespoons (1/4 stick) unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes', u'1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar', u'1/4 teaspoon salt', u'2/3 cup hazelnuts, toasted , husked, coarsely chopped', u'1/3 cup heavy whipping cream', u'1 1/2 teaspoons instant espresso powder', u'4 ounces high-quality milk chocolate (such as Lindt, Perugina, or Valrhona), chopped', u'1 tablespoon unsalted butter', u'1 tablespoon cacao nibs*', u'Special equipment: 1 13 3/4 x 4 1/2-inch rectangular tart pan with removable bottom'], 'preperation steps': [u'Blend flour, powdered sugar, and salt in processor. Add butter; using on/off turns, blend until mixture resembles coarse meal. Add 1 tablespoon ice water; process just until dough begins to clump together, adding more ice water by teaspoonfuls if dry. Transfer dough to 13 3/4 x 4 1/2-inch rectangular tart pan with removable bottom. Press dough onto bottom and up sides of pan. Freeze crust 20 minutes.', u'Meanwhile, position rack in center of oven and preheat to 375\xb0F. Bake crust until golden brown and cooked through, about 30 minutes. Cool crust completely in pan on rack.', u'Stir sugar and 1/4 cup water in heavy medium saucepan over medium heat until sugar dissolves. Increase heat and boil without stirring until syrup is medium amber, occasionally brushing down sides of pan with wet pastry brush and swirling pan, about 8 minutes. Remove pan from heat. Add cream (mixture will bubble up). Place saucepan over medium heat; stir until caramel bits dissolve. Add butter, vinegar, and salt; stir until butter melts. Stir in hazelnuts. Spoon filling into crust. Chill until cold and set, about 30 minutes.', u'Combine cream and espresso powder in small saucepan. Bring to simmer over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally, until espresso powder is dissolved. Remove from heat. Add chocolate and butter; stir until smooth. Spread chocolate mixture over caramel. Sprinkle with cacao nibs. Chill tart until topping is set, about 1 hour. DO AHEAD: Can be made 2 days ahead. Cover and keep chilled.', u'Remove tart pan sides. Place tart on platter; cut crosswise into 8 bars and serve.', u'Bits of shell-roasted cacao beans; available at many specialty foods stores and from chocosphere.com.'], 'chef': u'Rochelle Palermo', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/milk-chocolate-caramel-tart-with-hazelnuts-and-espresso-357278', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 servings', 'recipe title': u'Milk Chocolate-Caramel Tart with Hazelnuts and Espresso', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Kid-size and super-easy to make, these Halloween cupcakes are the perfect festive treats for the holiday.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': u'Per serving: 163.9 kcal calories, 51.6 % calories from fat, 9.5 g fat, 4.0 g saturated fat, 27.4 mg cholesterol, 18.8 g carbohydrates, 0.4 g dietary fiber, 14.4 g total sugars, 18.4 g net carbohydrates, 1.4 g protein (Analysis includes 2 teaspoons frosting per cupcake.)\n\nNutritional analysis provided by Bon App\xe9tit', 'recommendation': u'84%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 cup self-rising flour', u'2/3 cup (packed) golden brown sugar', u'2 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice', u'1 large egg', u'1/2 cup canned pure pumpkin', u'1/3 cup vegetable oil', u'1/3 cup sour cream', u'1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract', u'Chopped crystallized ginger (optional)', u'1 8-ounce package cream cheese, room temperature', u'1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, room temperature', u'2 cups powdered sugar', u'Orange and black food coloring; orange, black, white, and yellow candies and sugar crystals', u'Special Equipment: Mini muffin pans 13/4x1-inch paper liners'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F. Line 24 mini muffin cups with 1 3/4x 1-inch paper liners. Mix flour, golden brown sugar, and pumpkin pie spice in large bowl. Whisk egg, canned pure pumpkin, vegetable oil, sour cream, and vanilla extract in medium bowl. Add mixture to dry ingredients; stir to fully combine. Spoon batter into paper liners (batter will almost fill liners). Scatter crystallized ginger over, if desired. Bake cupcakes until tester inserted into center comes out clean, about 16 minutes. Remove cupcakes from pan and let cool completely on rack. Using electric mixer, beat cream cheese and butter in large bowl to blend. Beat in powdered sugar.', u'Divide frosting among 3 bowls. Tint frosting in first bowl with orange coloring (or combine red and yellow coloring to make orange) and frosting in second bowl with black coloring, keeping frosting in third bowl white. Chill frosting 2 hours or until firm enough to easily spread. Frost cupcakes; decorate using candy and sugar crystals as desired.'], 'chef': u'The Bon App\xe9tit Test Kitchen', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/mini-halloween-pumpkin-cupcakes-355190', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 24 ', 'recipe title': u'Mini Halloween Pumpkin Cupcakes', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Using miso on the turkey is a great way to get wonderfully moist meat \u2014 always a challenge at Thanksgiving. The skin doesn't get as crisp as it would without, but we think the succulent results are well worth the trade-off. The miso won't give the turkey an Asian flavor, but it will add a rich meatiness to the gravy. Don't use a brined or kosher turkey for this recipe or the bird will be too salty (miso has a high sodium content).", 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 medium onion, quartered but left unpeeled', u'1/2 cup miso (white or red fermented-soybean paste)', u'1 stick (1/2 cup) unsalted butter, softened, plus additional melted butter (from 1/2 stick) if turkey drippings yield less than 1/2 cup fat', u'1 teaspoon black pepper', u'1 (12- to 14-lb) turkey, any feathers and quills removed with tweezers or needlenose pliers, and neck and giblets reserved for another use if desired', u'1/2 teaspoon salt', u'1 cup water', u'9 cupsturkey stock', u'3/4 cup all-purpose flour', u'Special equipment: 2 small metal picks or skewers; kitchen string; a 19- by 13-inch flameproof roasting pan with a rack; an instant-read thermometer'], 'preperation steps': [u'Peel and chop 1 onion quarter, then pulse in a food processor until finely chopped. Add miso and pur\xe9e until smooth. Add 1/2 stick softened butter and 1/2 teaspoon pepper and pur\xe9e until combined (mixture will appear curdled).', u'Put oven rack in lowest position and preheat oven to 350\xb0F.', u'Rinse turkey inside and out, then pat dry. Working from large cavity end, gently run your fingers between skin and meat of breast to loosen skin, being careful not to tear skin. Push miso butter under skin, including thighs and drumsticks, and massage skin from outside to spread miso evenly (see Kitchen Notebook, page 230). Sprinkle large cavity with salt and remaining 1/2 teaspoon pepper. Fold neck skin under body and secure with metal picks or skewers, then stuff large cavity with remaining 3 onion quarters. Tie drumsticks together with string and tuck wings under body.', u'Put turkey on rack in roasting pan and roast 30 minutes.', u'Melt remaining 1/2 stick softened butter and brush over turkey, then add water (1 cup) to roasting pan. Tent turkey with foil and roast, basting every 30 minutes and adding more water to pan if necessary, until thermometer inserted into fleshy part of a thigh (do not touch bone) registers 170\xb0F, 2 to 2 1/2 hours more (total roasting time: 2 1/2 to 3 hours). Remove foil for last 30 minutes of roasting if turkey is pale. Transfer turkey to a platter (reserve roasting pan) and let stand, loosely covered, 25 minutes (temperature will rise to 180\xb0F while turkey stands). Remove picks from turkey.', u'Pour pan juices through a fine-mesh sieve into a 2-quart glass measure, then skim off and reserve fat. (If there is less than 1/2 cup fat, add enough melted butter to total 1/2 cup.) Pour pan juices and 8 cups turkey stock into a 3-quart saucepan and bring to a simmer. Straddle roasting pan across 2 burners, then add remaining cup turkey stock and deglaze roasting pan by boiling over moderately high heat, stirring and scraping up brown bits, 1 minute. Pour through sieve into remaining stock and bring to a simmer.', u'Cook flour and 1/2 cup reserved fat in a 4-quart heavy pot over moderately low heat, whisking, 5 minutes. Add hot stock mixture in a fast stream, whisking constantly to prevent lumps, then simmer, whisking occasionally, until gravy is thickened, about 10 minutes. Stir in any turkey juices accumulated on platter and season gravy with salt and pepper.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/miso-rubbed-turkey-with-turkey-gravy-232984', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 to 10 servings', 'recipe title': u'Miso-Rubbed Turkey with Turkey Gravy', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': None, 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'13 large egg whites', u'1/4 teaspoon salt', u'2 1/2 cups superfine granulated sugar', u'1 1/2 tablespoons cornstarch', u'1 1/2 tablespoons distilled white vinegar', u'2 lb strawberries, halved or quartered if large', u'3 tablespoons fresh lime juice', u'1/4 cup plus 1 1/2 tablespoons granulated sugar', u'1 lb blackberries', u'2 1/2 cups chilled heavy cream', u'2 teaspoons vanilla', u'Special equipment: a standing electric mixer'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 250\xb0F and line 2 large baking sheets with parchment.', u"Swirl whites in a metal bowl set over a saucepan of simmering water until barely warm to the touch. Beat whites with salt in a standing electric mixer until they hold soft peaks. Beat in 2 cups superfine sugar and continue beating until mixture holds stiff, glossy peaks (see cooks' note, below). Stir together remaining 1/2 cup superfine sugar and cornstarch. Beat into meringue, then beat in vinegar.", u'Spoon 8 mounds of meringue (each about 2 inches high and approximately 1/2 cup) 1 inch apart on each lined baking sheet. Divide any remaining meringue among mounds. Bake in upper and lower thirds of oven, switching position of sheets halfway through baking, until crisp but still soft inside, 1 to 1 1/4 hours total. If meringues are still not crisp after 1 1/4 hours, turn off oven and cool in oven 1 hour. Transfer from parchment to racks to cool. (Meringues may stick if cooled completely on paper.)', u'Just before serving, toss strawberries with lime juice and 1/4 cup granulated sugar and let stand, tossing occasionally until sugar is dissolved, 10 minutes. Add blackberries and toss to coat.', u'Beat cream with vanilla and remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons granulated sugar with cleaned beaters. Tap meringues gently with back of a spoon to create indentations, then mound some whipped cream and berries onto each.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/mixed-berry-pavlovas-103405', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 16', 'recipe title': u'Mixed Berry Pavlovas', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"For seven centuries, Moors and Christians fought one another in Spain, but in the guise of black beans and rice they surrendered to each other's charms within the all-embracing New World pot. Like the hybrid culture that flourished in medieval Spain, the rice dish known as moros y cristianos is an exemplar of exchange between civilizations.", 'rating': u'0/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'0%', 'ingredient list': [u'8 ounces dried black beans', u'1 medium yellow onion (about 8 ounces), peeled', u'1 medium green bell pepper (about 7 ounces), cored, seeded, and halved', u'6 Caribbean sweet peppers (aj\xedes dulces) or 1 cubanelle pepper', u'1 ham hock (optional)', u"2 cups (about 13 ounces) long-grain rice or Uncle Ben's converted rice", u'2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil', u'4 ounces slab bacon, diced', u'1 medium yellow onion, finely chopped (about 1 1/4 cups)', u'1 medium green bell pepper (about 7 ounces), cored, seeded, deveined, and finely chopped (about 1 cup)', u'1 teaspoon ground cumin', u'1 teaspoon dried oregano', u'1 bay leaf', u'1 tablespoon distilled white vinegar, or to taste', u'1 tablespoon dry sherry, or to taste', u'2 teaspoons salt, or to taste'], 'preperation steps': [u'Rinse and pick over the beans. Place in a medium heavy-bottomed pot with 2 1/2 quarts water, the onion, bell pepper, aj\xedes or cubanelle pepper, and the ham hock, if using, and bring to a boil over high heat. Lower the heat to medium and simmer, uncovered, until the beans are tender but still retain their shape, about 2 hours. Drain, reserving 4 cups of the cooking liquid. Discard the vegetables and ham hock; you should have 2 cups cooked beans.', u'Place the rice in a medium bowl, cover with cold tap water, and swirl the rice, then drain, holding the rice in place with one hand. Repeat the process as many times as necessary until the water runs clear. Drain well in a sieve or strainer. Heat the oil in the heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat. Add the diced bacon and saut\xe9 until golden, about 3 minutes. Add the onion, green pepper, cumin, oregano, and bay leaf and saut\xe9 until the onion is soft, about 5 minutes.', u'Add the rice and stir to coat thoroughly. Add the beans and the reserved bean cooking liquid, then add the vinegar, sherry, and salt. Mix well and taste for seasoning; add a dash more of sherry, vinegar, and/or spices if needed. The cooking liquid should be flavorful. Cook, uncovered, until most of the liquid is absorbed and small craters have formed on the surface of the rice. Fluff the rice slightly with a kitchen fork, reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting, and cook, tightly covered, for 20 minutes.', u'Remove from the heat and let stand, uncovered, for at least 10 minutes before serving.'], 'chef': u'Maricel Presilla', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/moors-and-christians-em-moros-y-cristianos-em-51203610', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 8', 'recipe title': u'Moors and Christians (Moros y Cristianos)', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"David Leite's neighbor, Danny Pring, insists that the goose be served with red currant jelly.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'73%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 13-pound goose (thawed if frozen); neck, heart, gizzard, and wing tips reserved for stock', u'3 tablespoons Dijon mustard', u'2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice', u'2 garlic cloves, minced', u'1 teaspoon salt', u'1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper', u'1/2 teaspoon dried savory', u'3 14-ounce cans low-salt chicken broth', u'1 carrot, cut into 1-inch pieces', u'1 small onion, sliced', u'3 1/2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar', u'3 fresh Italian parsley sprigs', u'Reserved goose neck (cut into 3-inch pieces), heart, gizzard, and wing tips', u'1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons tawny Port', u'1/3 cup all purpose flour'], 'preperation steps': [u'Position oven rack in bottom third of oven and preheat to 425\xb0F. Remove excess fat and skin from main body cavity and neck cavity. Pierce goose with sharp fork, especially where fat is thickest on legs and lower breast. Sprinkle cavities and skin with salt and pepper. Tie legs together to hold shape. Place goose, breast side down, on V-shaped rack set in roasting pan. Add enough water to pan to reach depth of 1/2 inch. Roast 40 minutes. Spoon off fat from surface of liquid in pan; reserve 1/4 cup fat.', u'Reduce oven temperature to 350\xb0F. Using tongs as aid, turn goose onto 1 side. Roast 30 minutes. Turn goose onto second side. Roast 30 minutes.', u'Whisk mustard, lemon juice, garlic, salt, pepper, and savory in small bowl to blend. Turn goose breast side up. Brush goose with mustard-garlic mixture. Roast until meat thermometer inserted into thickest part of thigh registers 175\xb0F and juices run clear when thigh is pierced with fork, about 50 minutes. Transfer goose to platter; tent loosely with foil to keep warm. Reserve pan juices.', u'Bring all ingredients to boil in large saucepan. Reduce heat to medium and simmer, uncovered, until reduced to 3 cups, occasionally skimming surface, about 1 hour. Strain stock into bowl; spoon off fat.', u'Spoon off fat from top of reserved juices in roasting pan. Add 1/2 cup Port to pan. Place roasting pan atop 2 burners and boil until mixture is reduced to 1 cup, whisking occasionally, about 5 minutes. Whisk flour and reserved 1/4 cup fat in medium saucepan over medium-low heat until roux is light brown, about 5 minutes. Gradually whisk in Port mixture and 2 1/2 cups degreased stock. Simmer until gravy thickens enough to coat spoon, whisking constantly, about 3 minutes. Stir in 2 tablespoons Port. Season with salt and pepper. Carve goose and serve with gravy.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/mustard-and-garlic-roast-goose-108956', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 6 servings', 'recipe title': u'Mustard and Garlic Roast Goose', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Arab salad, chopped salad, Israeli salad\u2014whatever you choose to call it, there is no escaping it. Wherever you go, a Jerusalemite is most likely to have a plate of freshly chopped vegetables\u2014tomato, cucumber, and onion, dressed with olive oil and lemon juice\u2014served next to whatever else they are having. It\'s a local affliction, quite seriously. Friends visiting us in London always complain of feeling they ate "unhealthily" because there wasn\'t a fresh salad served with every meal.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'scant 1 cup / 200 g Greek yogurt and 3/4 cup plus 2 tbsp / 200 ml whole milk, or 1 2/3 cups / 400 ml buttermilk (replacing both yogurt and milk)', u'2 large stale Turkish flatbread or naan (9 oz /250 g in total)', u'3 large tomatoes (13 oz / 380 g in total), cut into 2/3-inch / 1.5cm dice', u'3 1/2 oz / 100 g radishes, thinly sliced', u'3 Lebanese or mini cucumbers (9 oz / 250 g in total), peeled and chopped into 2/3-inch / 1.5cm dice', u'2 green onions, thinly sliced', u'1/2 oz / 15 g fresh mint', u'scant 1 oz / 25 g flat-leaf parsley, coarsely chopped', u'1 tbsp dried mint', u'2 cloves garlic, crushed', u'3 tbsp freshly squeezed lemon juice', u'1/4 cup / 60 ml olive oil, plus extra to drizzle', u'2 tbsp cider or white wine vinegar', u'3/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper', u'1 1/2 tsp salt', u'1 tbsp sumac or more to taste, to garnish'], 'preperation steps': [u'If using yogurt and milk, start at least 3 hours and up to a day in advance by placing both in a bowl. Whisk well and leave in a cool place or in the fridge until bubbles form on the surface. What you get is a kind of homemade buttermilk, but less sour.', u'Tear the bread into bite-size pieces and place in a large mixing bowl. Add your fermented yogurt mixture or commercial buttermilk, followed by the rest of the ingredients, mix well, and leave for 10 minutes for all the flavors to combine.', u'Spoon the fattoush into serving bowls, drizzle with some olive oil, and garnish generously with sumac.'], 'chef': u'Yotam Ottoloenghi and Sami Tamimi', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/naamas-fattoush-51115620', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 6', 'recipe title': u"Na'ama's Fattoush", 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'For this recipe we call for a 13 1/2- by 4- by 1-inch rectangular tart pan with a removable fluted rim; you could also use an 8 1/2- by 1-inch round tart pan (both have about a 3 3/4-cup capacity).', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'96%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 firm-ripe medium nectarine', u'5 large egg yolks', u'1/3 cup granulated sugar', u'2 tablespoons fresh lime', u'2 tablespoons unsalted', u'1/8 teaspoon vanilla', u'3/4 stick (6 tablespoons) cold unsalted butter', u'1 cup all-purpose flour', u'1/3 cup packed dark brown sugar', u'3/4 teaspoon salt', u'4 firm-ripe medium nectarines', u'1/3 cup peach jam'], 'preperation steps': [u'Halve and pit nectarine. Cut halves into pieces and in a blender pur\xe9e until smooth. In a heavy saucepan whisk together pur\xe9e, yolks, granulated sugar, lime juice, butter, and vanilla. Cook mixture over moderately low heat, whisking constantly, until it just reaches a boil, about 7 minutes, and immediately remove pan from heat. Strain curd through a sieve into a bowl and cool, its surface covered with a buttered round of wax paper. Chill curd at least 2 hours and up to 2 days.', u'Preheat oven to 375\xb0F.', u'Cut butter into pieces. In a food processor pulse flour, brown sugar, and salt until combined well. Add butter and blend until a dough begins to form (mixture should hold together when squeezed between fingers). Press dough evenly into bottom and up sides of a 13 1/2- by 4- by 1-inch rectangular tart pan with a removable fluted rim. Bake crust in middle of oven 20 minutes and cool in pan on a rack. Crust may be made 2 days ahead and kept in pan, covered, at room temperature.', u'Halve and pit nectarines. Cut halves into 1/4-inch-thick slices. Spoon curd into shell, smoothing top, and arrange nectarine slices decoratively on top. In a small saucepan heat jam over low heat until hot. Pour jam through a sieve into a bowl, pressing hard on solids. Lightly brush fruit with glaze. Chill tart, loosely covered with plastic wrap, until ready to serve. Tart may be made 1 day ahead and chilled, covered.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/nectarine-lime-curd-tart-with-a-brown-sugar-crust-15128', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 4 generously', 'recipe title': u'Nectarine Lime Curd Tart with a Brown-Sugar Crust', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'The ultimate chocolate cake.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'67%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 cups sifted all purpose flour', u'1 1/4 teaspoons baking soda', u'1/2 teaspoon salt', u'3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature', u'2 cups firmly packed golden brown sugar', u'2 large eggs, room temperature', u'2 large egg yolks, room temperature', u'5 ounces unsweetened chocolate, melted and cooled', u'1 1/2 cups buttermilk, room temperature', u'Bittersweet Chocolate frosting', u'13 walnut halves (optional)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F. Butter bottoms of three 9-inch-diameter cake pans with 1 1/2-inch-high sides. Line bottoms with waxed paper.', u'Mix flour, soda, and salt in small bowl. Using electric mixer, cream butter in large bowl until light. Gradually add sugar and beat until fluffy. Add eggs 1 at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in yolks, then melted chocolate. Mix in dry ingredients alternately with buttermilk, beginning and ending with dry ingredients. Divide batter among prepared pans. Bake until tester inserted in centers comes out clean, about 25 minutes. Transfer cakes to racks and cool 5 minutes. Run small sharp knife around pan sides to loosen. Unmold cakes onto paper towel-lined racks. Cool completely.', u'Peel paper off cakes. Place 1 cake layer on platter. Slide waxed paper strips just under sides of cake. Spread 3/4 cup frosting over, Top with second cake layer. Spread with 3/4 cup frosting. Top with third cake layer. Spread remaining frosting decoratively over top and sides of cake. Remove waxed paper strips. Arrange walnuts around top edge and center of cake if desired. (Can be prepared 1 day ahead. Cover with cake dome; store at room temperature.)'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/new-england-heirloom-cake-233679', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 12 servings', 'recipe title': u'New England Heirloom Cake', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Worth It', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'67%', 'ingredient list': [u'Small (9" x 13") rimmed baking sheet', u'Heatproof spatula or wooden spoon', u'Candy thermometer', u'Large cutting board', u'Cooking spray or vegetable oil', u'3 cups (575 g) granulated sugar', u'1/2 cup (175 g) honey', u'1/2 cup (120 g) water', u'Pinch of cream of tartar', u'1 cup (150 g) cornstarch', u"1 cup (130 g) confectioners' sugar", u'2 1/2 cups (600 g) water', u'1 teaspoon (3 g) cream of tartar', u'2 1/2 teaspoons (12 g) rosewater', u'2 cups (300 g) shelled roasted unsalted pistachios (if you can only find them raw, check out how to toast them yourself on page 284)', u'2 or 3 drops red food coloring (optional)', u"About 1/4 cup confectioners' sugar, for dusting the cutting board", u"1/2 cup cornstarch sifted together with 1 cup confectioners' sugar"], 'preperation steps': [u'1. Generously coat the baking sheet with cooking spray, and set it aside.', u'2. Make the sugar syrup: Combine the sugar, honey, water, and cream of tartar in a medium-size (4-quart) saucepan, and mix with the heatproof spatula to combine. Bring the mixture to a boil over high heat, and insert the candy thermometer. Reduce the heat to medium-high and cook, without stirring, until the temperature reaches 260\xb0F/127\xb0C (hard ball stage), about 15 minutes.', u"3. Meanwhile (keeping an eye on the sugar syrup), make the cornstarch mixture: In a large (6-quart) saucepan, whisk together the cornstarch, confectioners' sugar, water, and cream of tartar to combine. Once the sugar syrup reaches 250\xb0F/121\xb0C (firm ball stage), place the cornstarch mixture over medium heat and cook, stirring constantly with the whisk; it will thicken and boil quickly, 2 to 3 minutes. Turn off the heat, but leave the mixture on the hot burner; stir well a few times with a whisk, and set aside.", u"4. At this point, the sugar syrup should be close to 260\xb0F/127\xb0C (hard ball stage); when it reaches that temperature, remove it from the heat and carefully pour it into the cornstarch mixture. Stir well with the whisk to combine. Bring everything to a low boil over medium heat. Then reduce the heat to low and cook at a low simmer, stirring frequently with the spatula, until the mixture is thick and gluey and a light golden color, 30 to 45 minutes. Don't turn your back on it! You need to make sure to scrape the bottom of the pan with the spatula every few minutes to prevent scorching and lumps.", u'5. Remove the pan from the heat and add the flavorings: stir in the rosewater, pistachios, and food coloring (if using).', u'6. Wearing oven mitts, immediately pour the candy into the prepared baking sheet. Place a piece of plastic wrap directly on the surface of the candy to prevent it from forming a skin as it cools. Allow it to cool until it has set and is firm and cool to the touch, 6 to 8 hours.', u"7. Gently peel off the plastic wrap. Dust the cutting board with the confectioners' sugar. Run the tip of a paring knife between the candy and the sheet, and gently turn the candy out onto the prepared board.", u"8. Place the cornstarch mixture in a medium-size bowl. Generously coat a sharp chef's knife with cooking spray, and use a gentle slicing motion to cut the candy into 1-inch squares. Dredge the pieces in the cornstarch mixture until well coated.", u'Store the Turkish delights, layered with wax paper, in an airtight container at cool room temperature for up to 1 month.'], 'chef': u'Liz Gutman & Jen King', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/non-evil-turkish-delight-51139600', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes about 100 one-inch candies', 'recipe title': u'Non-Evil Turkish Delight', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This torte consists of three flavors of ice cream or frozen yogurt that are layered with Nutella, a creamy hazelnut-chocolate spread available in specialty foods stores and most supermarkets. Drop remaining Nutella by teaspoonfuls over ice cream, spacing drops evenly (do not spread). Freeze until firm, about 30 minutes. Spread vanilla ice cream evenly over. Using spatula, smooth top. Pipe reserved Nutella decoratively over top. Freeze just until Nutella is firm, about 30 minutes. Wrap torte in plastic and freeze at least 6 hours or overnight. (Can be prepared 1 week ahead. {'cook_time': None, 'description': None, 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': u'Per serving: 128.6 kcal calories, 38.4% calories from fat, 5.5 g fat, 0.6 g saturated fat, 0 mg cholesterol, 19.2 g carbohydrates, 1.2 g dietary fiber, 12.8 g total sugars, 18.0 g net carbohydrates, 1.6 g protein\n\nNutritional analysis provided by Bon App\xe9tit', 'recommendation': u'88%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 cups chopped stemmed dried figs (10 to 11 ounces)', u'1 cup water', u'6 tablespoons sugar', u'Pinch of salt', u'1 1/2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice', u'1 teaspoon vanilla extract', u'1 cup walnuts, toasted, coarsely chopped', u'Nonstick vegetable oil spray', u'1 3/4 cups old-fashioned oats', u'13/4 cups all purpose flour', u'1 1/4 cups (packed) dark brown sugar', u'2 teaspoons ground cinnamon', u'1 teaspoon baking soda', u'1/2 teaspoon salt', u'1 cup (2 sticks) chilled vegan "butter" (such as Earth Balance) or margarine, cut into 1/2-inch cubes', u'1 cup powdered sugar'], 'preperation steps': [u'Combine first 4 ingredients in heavy medium saucepan. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u"The Epicurious test kitchen baked up the most popular versions of banana bread on our site to discover what we like (or didn't like) about each one. Then we made our ultimate version: a sweet, nutty, and supremely moist loaf that is everything we could ever want in this classic quick bread.", 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'67%', 'ingredient list': [u'1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, at room temperature, plus more for pan', u'1 2/3 cups all-purpose flour, plus more for pan', u'4 medium very ripe bananas (about 13 ounces), peeled and mashed', u'1/4 cup sour cream', u'1 teaspoon vanilla extract', u'1 teaspoon baking powder', u'1/2 teaspoon baking soda', u'1/2 teaspoon kosher salt', u'1 cup (packed) dark brown sugar', u'2 large eggs, at room temperature', u'1/2 cup chopped toasted walnuts', u'A 9x5" loaf pan'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F. Grease a 9x5" loaf pan with butter and dust with flour, tapping out any excess.', u'Combine banana, sour cream, and vanilla in a medium bowl. Sift together flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a large bowl.', u'Using an electric mixer, beat butter and brown sugar on medium speed in another large bowl until light and fluffy, about 3 1/2 minutes. Add eggs one at a time and beat on medium speed until fully combined, about 1 minute each. Add banana mixture and beat until just combined, about 30 seconds. Add dry ingredients in 2 batches, beating on low after each addition and scraping down sides of bowl if necessary, until fully incorporated, about 20 seconds per batch. Fold in walnuts. Transfer batter to prepared pan and smooth top with a spatula.', u'Bake, rotating halfway through, until batter is set, top is dark golden brown and starting to crack, sides are starting to pull away from pan, and a tester inserted into center of bread comes out clean, 60\u201365 minutes. Cool in pan on a wire rack at least 15 minutes. Run a butter knife around perimeter of pan to loosen loaf, then tap pan gently on its side until loaf releases. Transfer to a cutting board or plate and let cool completely before slicing.'], 'chef': u'da Boone', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/our-favorite-banana-bread-56389378', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes one 9x5" loaf', 'recipe title': u'Our Favorite Banana Bread', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This perennial favorite has just the right mix of hearty sausage, vibrant spinach, and a perfectly balanced three-cheese blend. With a quick-cooking sauce and no-fuss, no-boil noodles, the assembly is easy, and one pan feeds a large crowd.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'58%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil', u'1 pound sweet Italian sausage, casings removed', u'1 medium onion, chopped', u'3/4 teaspoon kosher salt', u'1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper', u'4 garlic cloves, minced', u'1/2 teaspoon red-pepper flakes, plus more to taste', u'2 tablespoons tomato paste', u'Two 28-ounce cans whole tomatoes', u'2 teaspoons dried oregano', u'Two 15-ounce containers part-skim ricotta cheese', u'1 1/2 cups packed basil leaves', u'1/2 cup grated Parmesan (about 2 ounces)', u'2 large egg yolks', u'3/4 teaspoon kosher salt', u'1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper', u'2 10-ounce packages frozen chopped spinach, thawed, or 1 1/2 pounds fresh spinach, steamed', u'Pinch kosher salt', u'Vegetable-oil cooking spray', u'9 no-boil lasagna noodles (such as Barilla)', u'1 pound fresh mozzarella, grated (about 4 cups)', u'9 x 13 x 2-inch baking dish, preferably glass'], 'preperation steps': [u'Position the rack in the upper third of the oven and preheat to 375\xb0F.', u'In a large pot over medium-high heat, heat the oil. Add the sausage, onion and 3/4 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper; cook, breaking up sausage with a wooden spoon, until browned and cooked through, 8 to 10 minutes. Reduce heat to medium and add garlic, red-pepper flakes, and tomato paste; cook, stirring often, until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes more. Add tomatoes (along with their juice) and oregano; bring to a simmer, and cook, breaking up the tomatoes with a wooden spoon until in small pieces, about 5 minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning, adding more red-pepper flakes if desired.', u'In the bowl of a food processor, combine all of the filling ingredients and process until mostly smooth.', u'Squeeze the spinach in a paper towel or clean dishcloth until very dry. Transfer to a bowl and season with a pinch of salt.', u'Coat baking dish with cooking spray and spread the bottom with 2 cups sauce. Top with a layer of three noodles, then a third of the ricotta mixture (about 1 1/3 cups), and a third of the spinach (about 2/3 cup). Sprinkle with 1 cup grated mozzarella.', u'Repeat twice more, skipping the mozzarella on the third layer. Top the lasagna with the remaining sauce. Sprinkle the remaining 2 cups mozzarella in clusters so some of the sauce peeks through.', u'Place the baking pan on a rimmed baking sheet. Lightly spray a piece of foil with cooking spray, cover the lasagna, and bake for 45 minutes. Remove the foil and continue baking until lightly browned and bubbly, about 20 minutes more. Let cool at least 10 minutes before serving.', u'DO AHEAD: The sauce can be prepared up to 2 days in advance and refrigerated. The filling can be prepared up to 1 day in advance and refrigerated.'], 'chef': u'da Boone', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/our-favorite-lasagna-with-sausage-spinach-and-three-cheeses-51253440', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 to 10 servings', 'recipe title': u'Our Favorite Lasagna with Sausage, Spinach, and Three Cheeses', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Creamy, cheesy macaroni with a light, crunchy topping: This is the macaroni and cheese that dreams are made of. A hit of ground mustard brings an unexpected kick to this guaranteed crowd pleaser.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'81%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more for baking dish', u'2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil', u'2 cups panko (Japanese breadcrumbs)', u'2 large garlic cloves, minced', u'2 ounces finely grated Parmesan (about 1/2 cup)', u'1/2 teaspoon kosher salt', u'1 pound dried elbow macaroni', u'1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter', u'6 tablespoons all-purpose flour', u'4 cups whole milk', u'3/4 cup heavy cream', u'16 ounces coarsely grated extra-sharp cheddar (about 6 cups)', u'2 ounces grated Parmesan (about 1/2 cup)', u'2 teaspoons kosher salt', u'1/2 teaspoon ground white pepper', u'1 1/2 tablespoons mustard powder', u'9- by 13-inch baking dish'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat oven to 400\xb0F with rack in the middle of oven. Add panko and garlic; cook, stirring, until crumbs are golden brown, 4 to 6 minutes. Transfer crumbs to a medium bowl, stir in 1/2 cup Parmesan and salt, and set aside.', u'Add macaroni to boiling salted water and cook until just al dente (avoid overcooking). Drain macaroni and set aside. In a large wide pot over medium-low heat, melt the butter. Sprinkle flour over butter, whisking to incorporate and make a roux. Cook, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon, until roux is light golden, about 4 minutes. Gradually pour in milk and cream, whisking constantly to incorporate and make a b\xe9chamel sauce. Raise heat to medium-high and bring sauce to a low boil, whisking constantly. Reduce to a simmer, whisking occasionally, and cook until b\xe9chamel sauce is thick and coats the back of a spoon, about 3 minutes more.', u'Add the salt, pepper, and mustard powder. Add the cheeses in three batches, whisking until each addition is completely melted before adding more. Remove from heat.', u'Add the drained macaroni to the pot with the cheese sauce and stir well to coat. Transfer macaroni mixture to the buttered baking dish and place on a rimmed baking sheet. Sprinkle topping evenly over macaroni and bake until golden and bubbling, 18 to 23 minutes. Let cool 15 minutes before serving.'], 'chef': u'da Boone', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/our-favorite-macaroni-and-cheese-51255890', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Serves 12', 'recipe title': u'Our Favorite Macaroni and Cheese', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Steamed spinach, mashed potatoes, and oatmeal cookies would fit the rustic theme.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'89%', 'ingredient list': [u'3 tablespoons butter', u'4 fully cooked sausages (13 ounces total)', u'1 medium onion, sliced', u'1 medium-size tart apple, such as Granny Smith, peeled, cored, sliced', u'1 cup apple cider or apple juice', u'2 tablespoons chopped fresh sage', u'2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice'], 'preperation steps': [u'Melt 1 tablespoon butter in large skillet over medium heat. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'I have written a recipe for panettone dressing before: the sweet seasonal fruit bread was cubed, toasted, and mixed with Italian sausage; this is very different, not least because I see it not as an accompaniment to turkey (which has its own interior stuffing) but to be served, at parties or over cocktails, in small squares, like savory brownies.', 'rating': u'0/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'0%', 'ingredient list': [u'4 echalion or banana shallots, or 2 onions (approx. 8 ounces total)', u'2 apples (approx. 8 ounces total)', u'14 ounces pancetta slices or rindless streaky bacon', u'2 stalks celery', u'4 large fresh sage leaves', u'3 tablespoons garlic-flavored oil', u'1 1/2 cups (approx. 7 ounces) vacuum-packed chestnuts', u'zest and juice 1 unwaxed lemon', u'1 pound panettone (or pandoro), slightly stale, sliced', u'2 eggs', u'olive oil, for greasing', u'aluminum foil pan or ovenproof dish approx. 9 x 13 inches'], 'preperation steps': [u"Peel and halve the shallots (or peel and quarter the onions) and quarter and core the apples, and roughly cut up the pancetta (or bacon). Drop the shallot or onion and the apple pieces into the bowl of a food processor along with the celery stalks, snapped in half, and the sage leaves, and process in a short burst to start the chopping, before adding the roughly cut pancetta (or bacon), and then blitz at full speed until finely chopped. Don't worry about the mixture's wetness; mush is what I expect. You can chop everything by hand, though; in which case, don't expect to get everything as ground up as it would in the processor. Anything goes.", u"Heat the garlic-flavored oil in a wide, heavy frying pan and fry this mixture, stirring every now and again, for 10\u201315 minutes, until the vegetables et al. have softened. Remove the fried mixture to a large bowl, crumble in the chestnuts, grate in the lemon zest and squeeze in the juice, then tear and crumble in the panettone, and\u2014I use my hands for this\u2014combine everything into a squidgy, fragrant paste. (If you're making this in advance, leave it to cool at this stage, then cover and transfer to the refrigerator where it can stand for up to 2 days.)", u'When you are ready to cook this, preheat the oven to 400\xb0F and let the dressing come to room temperature. Uncover the bowl, beat the eggs and mix them in, then spread the mixture into a foil pan or lightly greased ovenproof dish, and bake for 25\u201330 minutes, until the edges brown and begin to come away from the pan or dish and a cake tester comes out clean.', u"For appetizers, let the pan cool for 30 minutes and then cut into 48 little bite-sized squares\u2014or into 24 larger pieces to accompany roasted meat, if you'd prefer."], 'chef': u'Nigella Lawson', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/panettone-dressing-squares-51198210', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 48 little squares', 'recipe title': u'Panettone Dressing Squares', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'This is a classic Mayan dish from Yucat\xe1n made with the minimum of ingredients. Warmed corn tortillas are dipped into a pumpkin seed sauce from which the green oil has been extracted, and flavored with epazote. The tortillas are filled with chopped hard-cooked egg and topped with a tomato sauce. The final touch is given by little decorative pools of the green oil. Great care has to be taken to ensure that these ingredients are the freshest \u2014 slightly rancid or bitter pumpkin seeds can ruin it \u2014 and great care also should be taken in the preparation.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'100%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 1/2 cups (657ml) water', u'2 large leafy stems of epazote', u'1 scant teaspoon sea salt', u'8 ounces (225g) hulled raw pumpkin seeds, about 1 2/3 cups (313ml)', u'12 freshly made, warm corn tortillas, 5 to 5 1/2 inches (13-14cm) in diameter', u'5 large hard-cooked eggs, shelled, roughly chopped, and salted', u'1 cup (250ml) salsa', u'2 large hard-cooked eggs, white and yolks separated and finely chopped', u'12 epazote leaves (optional)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Have ready a warmed, not hot, serving dish or warmed individual dishes.', u'Put the water, epazote, and salt into a small pan and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer for about 5 minutes.', u'Spread the pumpkin seeds in a thin layer over the bottom of a large skillet and heat through gently over low heat, turning them over from time to time. The seeds will swell, but take care not to let them become even slightly golden or the sauce will lose its fresh green color. You might want to keep a lid handy because often some of the seeds will start jumping out of the pan. Spread the seeds onto a metal tray to cool completely before grinding to avoid the blades seizing up with the volatile oil.', u'Using an electric coffee/spice grinder, grind a portion of the seeds at a time to a slightly textured consistency, 5 to 6 seconds. If the seeds are ground too fine, then it will be more difficult to extract the oil.', u'Have a small glass bowl ready for the oil.', u"Put the ground seeds onto a plate that has a slight ridge around the rim. Measure out 1/4 cup (63ml) of the epazote broth and little by little sprinkle it \u2014 don't, for goodness' sake, pour the whole lot \u2014 over the seeds and work it with your hands, first having put the telephone on automatic answering. Gradually add the liquid until you have a crumbly but cohesive paste.", u"Tilt the plate a little to one side and put a folded cloth underneath to hold it in that position. Start squeezing the paste and you will see that drops of oil will begin to extrude. Add a little more warm liquid if necessary \u2014 you probably won't need the whole amount \u2014 and keep squeezing until you have collected almost 4 tablespoons of dark green oil. (This is pure vitamin E, and great for the hands.) Crumble the paste into a blender jar, add the remaining strained epazote broth, if desired, and blend until smooth.", u'Transfer the sauce to a skillet and warm through over the lowest possible heat, stirring almost constantly because the starch content of the seeds begins to swell and the particles tend to coagulate in the bottom of the pan.', u"Dip one of the warm tortillas into the sauce: it should be lightly covered. If the sauce is too thick, dilute it with a little extra warm water. Work as quickly as you can, dipping each tortilla into the sauce, holding it with tongs but supporting it with a spatula so you don't get left with a bit of broken tortilla in your tongs. Sprinkle some of the chopped egg across one-third of the tortilla, roll it up, and place it on the warmed dish.", u'When all the papadzules are assembled, pour the remaining sauce over them. (If the sauce has thickened and become grainy looking, put it back into the blender with a little extra warm water and blend until smooth.) Now pour on the tomato sauce and sprinkle the chopped egg whites and yolks. Decorate with the optional epazote. As a final touch, spoon in little pools of the oil. Serve immediately or the oil will sink back into the sauce and all that work will have been for naught! Of course, it is more colorful and attractive to serve the papadzules together on one serving dish.'], 'chef': u'Diana Kennedy', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/papadzules-108163', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 12 papadzules', 'recipe title': u'Papadzules', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Susan Dlott of Solon, Ohio, writes: "On our last visit to New York City, we spent the day watching the St. Patrick\'s Day parade, sightseeing, and shopping. We topped off the trip with a marvelous meal at La Dolce Vita. My entr\xe9e of pappardelle, pancetta, and mushrooms in a Sherry tomato cream sauce was simply unforgettable. I\'d like to duplicate it at home."', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'87%', 'ingredient list': [u'1/2 oz dried porcini* (1/4 cup)', u'1/2 cup hot water', u'3 tablespoons olive oil', u'1 medium onion, chopped', u'2 oz sliced pancetta, chopped', u'1 large garlic clove, minced', u'10 oz fresh white mushrooms, thinly sliced', u'1/3 cup medium-dry Sherry', u'1 (28- to 32-oz) can whole tomatoes in juice, chopped, reserving juice', u'2 Turkish bay leaves or 1 California', u'1/2 teaspoon salt', u'1/4 teaspoon black pepper', u'2 cups heavy cream', u'1 lb dried pappardelle or fettuccine', u'1/3 cup chopped fresh basil leaves', u'1/2 cup chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley', u'2 oz finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano (1 cup)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Soak porcini in hot water until softened, about 30 minutes. Pour soaking liquid through a sieve lined with a dampened paper towel into a small bowl and reserve.', u'Heat oil in a 4- to 5-quart heavy pot over moderately high heat until hot but not smoking, then saut\xe9 onion and pancetta, stirring, until golden, about 6 minutes. Add garlic and fresh mushrooms and saut\xe9, stirring, until liquid mushrooms give off is evaporated and mushrooms are lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Stir in porcini, reserved soaking liquid, and Sherry and boil, uncovered, until most of liquid is evaporated, about 5 minutes. Stir in tomatoes with juices, bay leaves, salt, and pepper and bring to a boil. Stir in cream, then reduce heat and simmer, uncovered, stirring occasionally, until thickened, about 45 minutes. Discard bay leaves.', u'Cook pappardelle in a 6- to 8-quart pot of boiling salted water until al dente, then drain. 3Stir basil and parsley into sauce, then toss pappardelle with just enough sauce to coat. Serve with cheese.', u'*Available at specialty foods shops and some supermarkets.'], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/pappardelle-with-mushrooms-and-tomato-cream-sauce-108394', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 6 main-course servings', 'recipe title': u'Pappardelle with Mushrooms and Tomato Cream Sauce', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Tender veal shanks get great depth of flavor from lecs\xf3, a kind of Hungarian sofrito of saut\xe9ed onions, frying peppers, and tomatoes, to which paprika and, in this case, stock are added. (Grimes found that Cubanelle peppers are the best substitute for the long, yellowish-green peppers found throughout Hungary.) Finished with sour cream, the sauce yields more than you need, but you'll be happy to have leftovers to serve over noodles, chicken, or pork.", 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'92%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 large onions, chopped (3 cups)', u'1 pound Cubanelle peppers (Italian green frying peppers; 4 large), coarsely chopped', u'3/4 cup vegetable oil, divided', u'2 Turkish bay leaves or 1 California', u'1 (14- to 15-ounce) can plum tomatoes in juice', u'2 tablespoons sweet Hungarian or regular paprika (not hot)', u'3 1/2 cups reduced-sodium chicken broth (28 fl ounces)', u'8 meaty cross-cut veal shanks (ossobuco; 7 to 7 1/2 pounds total), tied', u'2 cups dry white wine', u'1 (16-ounces) container sour cream', u'1 1/2 tablespoons all-purpose flour', u'Equipment: a 15-by 13-by 3-inch flameproof heavy roasting pan', u'Accompaniment: tiny dumplings with dill'], 'preperation steps': [u'Straddle roasting pan across 2 burners, then cook onions and peppers in 1/4 cup oil with bay leaves and 1 teaspoon salt over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until onions are softened, about 5 minutes. Add tomatoes with juice, breaking them up with a spoon, and cook, stirring, until liquid has evaporated, about 3 minutes. Sprinkle paprika over tomato mixture and stir just to combine, then immediately stir in broth. Remove from heat.', u'Preheat oven to 350\xb0F with rack in middle.', u'Pat shanks dry and season all over with 2 teaspoon salt. Heat 1/4 cup oil in a 12-inch heavy skillet over high heat until it shimmers, then add 4 shanks and brown, turning once, about 8 minutes total. Add shanks to tomato mixture in roasting pan. Pour off fat from skillet and wipe clean. Heat remaining 1/4 cup oil and brown remaining 4 shanks in same manner, transferring to roasting pan. Pour off fat from skillet, then add wine to skillet and boil, stirring and scraping up any brown bits, 15 to 20 seconds. Pour into roasting pan. Bring to a boil, then cover tightly with heavy-duty foil and braise in oven until very tender, 2 to 2 1/2 hours (depending on size).', u'Transfer shanks with a slotted spoon to a platter and keep warm, loosely covered with foil. Skim off any fat from braising liquid.', u'Whisk together sour cream and flour in a medium bowl. Whisk about 1 cup hot braising liquid into sour-cream mixture, then add mixture to remaining braising liquid in roasting pan and simmer (straddled across 2 burners) over low heat, whisking occasionally, until sauce is thickened, about 5 minutes.', u'Return shanks to sauce along with any meat juices from platter, and simmer until heated through, about 10 minutes. Discard bay leaves.'], 'chef': u'Paul Grimes', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/paprika-veal-shanks-351301', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 8 servings', 'recipe title': u'Paprika Veal Shanks', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"In 2013, I was a judge at a big pizza competition in Paris. In two days, I tasted seventy-three pizzas, most of them too rich and fussy for my taste. Let's just say that almost every entry featured smoked fish, foie gras, gold leaf, or edible flowers. But one extravagant ingredient that I thought really did work was truffles, and that inspired me to come up with this pizza that makes the most of truffle paste, wild mushrooms, and two of my favorite French cheeses: nutty Comt\xe9 and triple-cream Saint Andr\xe9. If you like, you can top the fully baked pizza with paper-thin slices of prosciutto or speck. And if you can get your hands on a fresh truffle, shave it on top right at the table. That's the kind of simple, earthy luxury I can really get behind.", 'rating': u'0/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'0%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 (13-ounce/370-gram) ball Master Dough , preferably with starter, made with Poolish', u'Flour, for dusting', u'8 ounces (225 grams) assorted mushrooms (such as pioppini, oyster, shiitake, and trumpet)', u'Olive oil, for saut\xe9ing', u'Fine sea salt and freshly ground black pepper', u'5 ounces (140 grams) part-skim mozzarella cheese, shredded (1-1/4 cups)', u'1-1/2 teaspoons (6 grams) truffle paste, or 1 fresh truffle (to taste)', u'1-1/2 ounces (45 grams) Saint Andr\xe9 Cheese', u'2 pizza baking stones or steels, pizza peel'], 'preperation steps': [u'Remove the dough ball from the refrigerator and leave wrapped at room temperature until the dough warms to 60\xb0F to 65\xb0F. Meanwhile, set up the oven with two pizza stones or baking steels and preheat to 500\xb0F for 1 hour.', u'Meanwhile, clean and trim the mushrooms so that they will all cook in about the same amount of time. Leave the pioppini and other small, delicate mushrooms whole. Slice the trumpets lengthwise into slices 1/8 inch thick.', u'Heat a generous film of oil in a skillet over medium-high heat until very hot. Add the larger mushroom pieces and saut\xe9 for 1 minute. Add the remaining mushrooms, season with fine sea salt and pepper, and saut\xe9, stirring often, for 2 to 3 minutes, until the mushrooms are softened but not browned. Remove from the heat and set aside.', u'Dust the work surface with the dusting mixture, then move the dough to the surface and dust the top.', u"Dust a wooden peel with the flour. Open the dough on the work surface to a 13-inch round with a slightly raised edge. Move the dough to the peel. As you work, shake the peel forward and backward to ensure the dough isn't sticking.", u'Mound the mozzarella in the center of the dough and use your fingertips to spread it evenly over the surface, leaving a 3/4-inch border. Scatter the mushrooms evenly over the top.', u'Slide the pizza onto the top stone. Bake for 7 minutes. Lift the pizza onto the peel, rotate it 180 degrees, and then transfer it to the bottom stone. Bake for 6 minutes, until the bottom is browned and crisp and the top is golden brown.', u'Transfer the pizza to a cutting board and cut into 6 wedges. Garnish each wedge with 1/4 teaspoon dollops of truffle paste, pinches of the Saint Andr\xe9, and shavings of Comt\xe9. Scatter the arugula over the top and finish with a drizzle of extra virgin oil and a pinch each of pepper and Maldon salt.'], 'chef': u'Tony Gemignani', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/parisian-51255650', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': None, 'recipe title': u'Parisian', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': None, 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'85%', 'ingredient list': [u'1 1/4 cups all-purpose flour', u'2 1/2 teaspoons finely chopped fresh sage', u'Rounded 1/4 teaspoon salt', u'3/4 stick (6 tablespoons) cold unsalted butter, cut into cubes', u'2 tablespoons cold vegetable shortening, cut into pieces', u'2 to 4 tablespoons ice water', u'1 large egg white (yolk reserved for filling), lightly beaten', u'2 ounces finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano (1 cup)', u'1 cup heavy cream', u'1 1/2 tablespoons olive oil', u'3/4 pound piece butternut squash, peeled, seeded, and cut into 1/2-inch pieces (2 cups)', u'3/8 teaspoon salt', u'1/4 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper', u'1 whole large egg', u'1 large egg yolk', u'Special equipment: a pastry or bench scraper; a 13 1/2- by 4-inch rectangular* or 8 1/2-inch round fluted tart pan with a removable bottom; pie weights or raw rice', u'Garnish: fried sage leaves'], 'preperation steps': [u'Combine flour, sage, and salt in a food processor, then add butter and shortening and pulse until mixture resembles coarse meal with some small (roughly pea-size) butter lumps. Drizzle with 2 tablespoons ice water and pulse until just incorporated.', u"Squeeze a small handful of dough: If it doesn't hold together, add more ice water, 1 tablespoon at a time, pulsing until just incorporated, then test again. (Do not overwork, or pastry will be tough.)", u'Turn out dough onto a lightly floured surface and divide into 4 portions. With heel of your hand, smear each portion once or twice in a forward motion to help distribute fat. Gather dough into a ball with scraper, then flatten into a 5-inch square. Chill dough, wrapped in plastic wrap, until firm, at least 1 hour.', u'Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 375\xb0F.', u'Roll out dough on a lightly floured surface with a floured rolling pin into a 17- by 8-inch rectangle and fit into tart pan. Trim excess dough, leaving a 1/2-inch overhang, then fold overhang inward and press against side of pan to reinforce edge. Lightly prick bottom and sides of shell all over with a fork. Chill until firm, about 30 minutes.', u'Line pastry shell with foil and fill with pie weights. Bake until sides are set and edges are pale golden, 18 to 20 minutes. Carefully remove foil and weights and bake shell until bottom is pale golden, 10 to 15 minutes more. Lightly brush bottom and sides of shell with egg white and continue to bake until dry and shiny, about 5 minutes. Cool completely in pan on a rack, about 15 minutes.', u'Reduce oven temperature to 325\xb0F.', u'Bring cheese and cream just to a boil in a small heavy saucepan over moderate heat, stirring occasionally. Remove from heat and steep, covered, 30 minutes. Pour steeped cream through a fine-mesh sieve into a bowl, pressing hard on cheese solids and then discarding them.', u'While cream steeps, heat oil in a 10-inch heavy nonstick skillet over moderately high heat until hot but not smoking, then saut\xe9 squash with 1/8 teaspoon salt and 1/8 teaspoon pepper, turning, until lightly browned on all sides, 8 to 10 minutes. Transfer with a slotted spoon to paper towels to drain and cool slightly.', u'Whisk together whole egg, yolk, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt and 1/8 teaspoon pepper in a bowl until combined. Add steeped cream, whisking until smooth.', u'Scatter squash evenly in tart shell and pour custard over. Bake until custard is just set and golden in patches, 30 to 35 minutes. Cool tart in pan on rack at least 20 minutes.', u'Halve tart crosswise, then cut in half lengthwise and cut each quarter into 8 pieces. Serve warm or at room temperature.', u"*Available at some cookware shops and Fante's Kitchen Wares Shop (fantes.com)."], 'chef': None, 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/parmesan-custard-tart-with-butternut-squash-108878', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u"Makes 32 hors d'oeuvres", 'recipe title': u'Parmesan Custard Tart with Butternut Squash', 'image_source': '/static/img/px/background.png'}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Watch out, potato chips. Kale chips are this year's latest craze in the snack department. Suddenly they seem to be everywhere, and for a hefty price. You won't believe how easy these crisps are to make at home for a fraction of the cost, and the Parmigiano and freshly ground pepper seasoning complements the kale beautifully. Bet you can't eat just one! Take it from us: When it comes to kale chips, curly kale beats Tuscan kale.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'67%', 'ingredient list': [u"3 pounds curly kale (see Cooks' notes)", u'4 tablespoons olive oil, divided', u'8 tablespoons finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, divided', u'2 teaspoons freshly ground black pepper, divided', u'Fine sea salt, divided', u'Special equipment: 2 very large bowls; 2 large (half-sheet 18- by 13-inch) rimmed sheet pans; parchment paper or nonstick foil'], 'preperation steps': [u'Heat oven to 275\xb0F with racks in upper and lower thirds.', u'Line rimmed sheet pans with parchment or nonstick foil.', u'Cut out and discard stems and center ribs from kale. Once the first half is in the oven, repeat with the other half of the kale.', u'Working in batches, spread leaves in a single layer on lined sheet pans and bake, switching positions of sheets halfway through, until crisp, about 25 minutes. Transfer crisps with a metal spatula to baking sheets or platters to cool. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'The Middle Eastern tone is part of this cake\'s appeal. A very nutty cake is suffused with a honey-citrus soaking syrup, much like baklava in concept but flour-free, making it suitable for Passover. A little goes a long way. For large Seder crowds, you can double the recipe and bake it in a 9-inch springform pan or a 9 by 13-inch rectangular pan. I serve this cake cut into small squares or diamonds placed in small muffin liner cups. Copeland Marks, in his book Sephardic Cooking, attributes this to Turkish cuisine. Joan Nathan calls it "Tishpishiti" in her book, Jewish Cooking in America and points to Syrian, as well as Turkish roots as does Claudia Roden in her book, Mediterranean Cookery. A nutty classic indeed! My version is inspired by a recipe simply called "Nut Cake," found in From My Grandmother\'s Kitchen, by Viviane Alcheck Miner with Linda Krinn. If you are interested in Sephardic recipes along with a very engaging family history, this book is a real find.', 'rating': u'4/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'94%', 'ingredient list': [u'3/4 cup granulated sugar', u'1/4 cup brown sugar', u'1/4 cup vegetable oil', u'3 eggs', u'3 tablespoons orange juice', u'1 teaspoon finely minced orange zest', u'1/4 teaspoon salt', u'1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon ( or 1/2 teaspoon for a more pronounced cinnamon flavor)', u'1/2 cup matzoh cake meal', u'1/2 cup finely chopped hazelnuts or almonds', u'1 cup finely chopped walnuts', u'2/3 cup granulated sugar', u'1/4 cup honey', u'1/3 cup orange juice', u'1/4 cup water', u'1 tablespoon lemon juice', u'1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon'], 'preperation steps': [u'Preheat the oven to 350\xb0F. Generously grease a 7-inch round layer cake pan (if you do not have one, you can use a round foil pan of the same or similar size available in the supermarket baking aisle).', u'In a medium-sized mixing bowl, using a wire whisk, beat the granulated and brown sugars with the oil and eggs until the mixture is thick and pale yellow. Stir in the remaining batter ingredients. Turn the batter into the prepared pan.', u'Bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the top is light brown and set. Cool for at least 20 minutes. Meanwhile, prepare the Soaking Syrup.', u'In a medium saucepan, combine the ingredients. Heat to dissolve the sugar and simmer for 5 to 10 minutes, until the mixture becomes syrupy. Cool well.', u'Pour the cooled syrup over the cooled cake, poking holes in the cake with a fork, to permit the syrup to penetrate. Allow it to stand for 2 to 4 hours to absorb the syrup. I prefer to refrigerate this cake so that while it is absorbing the liquid, it is also firming up. Also, chilling the cake offsets its sweetness and makes it easier to cut. Serve it on splayed muffin liners.'], 'chef': u'Marcy Goldman', 'r_link': '/recipes/food/views/passover-honey-nut-cake-in-soaking-syrup-109151', 'prep_time': None, 'servings': u'Makes 10 to 12 servings', 'recipe title': u'Passover Honey Nut Cake in Soaking Syrup', 'image_source': None}

{'cook_time': None, 'description': u"Think macaroni and cheese \u2014 only ten times better. This sophisticated version combines the nuttiness of Gruy\xe8re with the intense flavor of parmesan, juicy poached chicken, and a crisp, cheesy crust. If you're short on time, feel free to use cooked rotisserie chickens (see cooks' note, below). In that case, though, don't add salt to the sauce, as the stock made from the rotisserie chickens will already be salty.", 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'90%', 'ingredient list': [u'2 (3 1/2- to 4-lb) chickens', u'10 cups cold water', u'1 celery rib, quartered', u'1 carrot, quartered', u'1 medium onion, quartered', u'1 large garlic clove, smashed', u'2 fresh thyme sprigs', u'1 teaspoon salt', u'1/4 teaspoon whole black peppercorns', u'1 stick (1/2 cup) unsalted butter plus additional for greasing gratin dishes', u'1 garlic clove, minced', u'1/2 cup all-purpose flour', u'3 cups whole milk', u'1 cup cr\xe8me fra\xeeche (8 oz)', u'1 teaspoon salt', u'1/2 teaspoon black pepper', u'1/4 teaspoon cayenne', u'1 lb Gruy\xe8re, coarsely grated (6 cups)', u'1 oz Parmigiano-Reggiano, finely grated with a rasp (1 1/4 cups)', u'1 lb penne rigate or other short tubular pasta', u'6 cups fine fresh bread crumbs (from 14 slices firm white sandwich bread)', u'Special equipment: 2 (2 1/2- to 3-qt) shallow gratin dishes (13 by 9 inches)'], 'preperation steps': [u'Cut backbones, wing tips, and second joints of wings from chickens, then cut each chicken into quarters. Remove from heat and let stand, covered, 40 minutes.', u'Transfer chicken quarters with tongs to a shallow baking pan. Remove from heat and stir in cr\xe8me fra\xeeche, salt, pepper, cayenne, 2 cups Gruy\xe8re, and 1/2 cup Parmigiano-Reggiano.', u'While sauce simmers, cook pasta in a 6- to 8-quart pot of boiling salted water , uncovered, until not quite al dente, 8 to 10 minutes (pasta should still be firm), then drain in a colander. Divide pasta mixture between gratin dishes.', u'Toss bread crumbs with remaining 4 cups Gruy\xe8re and 3/4 cup Parmigiano-Reggiano, then sprinkle evenly over pasta mixture. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Peanut butter, eggs and milk deliver 13 grams of protein in each slice of this pie. In a thick-bottomed pot (to prevent burning), whisk milk with peanut butter and sugar over medium heat until steaming; remove from heat. Whisk peanut butter mixture into egg-vanilla mixture until combined; spoon filling into crust. Bake until filling is set at edges but center jiggles when you shake pan, 15 minutes. Heat broiler. {'cook_time': None, 'description': u'Imagine peanut brittle that is as delicate as lace, with the familiar buttery crunch.', 'rating': u'3/4', 'nutritional_info': None, 'recommendation': u'83%', 'ingredient list': [u'5 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into pieces', u'1/2 cup sugar', u'3 tablespoons light corn syrup', u'1 tablespoon heavy cream', u'1/2 cup all-purpose flour', u'1/4 teaspoon salt', u'3/4 cup salted roasted or cocktail peanuts, chopped', u'Special equipment: an 18- by 13-inch nonstick bakeware liner such as Silpat; a small offset spatula'], 'preperation steps': [u'Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 350\xb0F.
